title: ~게 되다 [ge doeda] (End up doing)
short_explanation: Used to express events or actions that occur unintentionally or as a result of another event or circumstance.
long_explanation: '~게 되다 [ge doeda]' is a grammar point in Korean used to indicate outcomes that are primarily out of the speaker's control, often unexpected or resulting from certain circumstances or events. It conveys the sense of 'end up doing' or 'come to do' in English. It is used to express a change or transition, the result of an event, or to describe the inevitable outcome of a certain situation.

examples.kr: 시험 공부를 하다가 잠이 들어서 결국 벼락치기를 하게 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Siheom gongbureul hadaga jami deureoseo gyeolguk byeorakchigireul hage doeeotseoyo.
examples.en: I fell asleep while studying for the exam, and ended up cramming at the last minute.

examples.kr: 팀원들이 모두 바빠서 저 혼자 발표 준비를 다 하게 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Timweondeuri modu bappaseo jeo honja balpyo junbireul da hage doeeotseoyo.
examples.en: All team members were busy, so I ended up preparing the presentation all by myself.

examples.kr: 지갑을 잃어버려서 엄마에게 돈을 빌려야 하게 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Jigabeul ilheobeoryeoseo eommaege doneul billyeoya hage doeeotseoyo.
examples.en: I lost my wallet, so I ended up having to borrow money from my mother.

examples.kr: 티켓이 매진되어 결국 그 콘서트를 보지 못하게 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Tiketi maejin doeeo gyeolguk geu konsoteureul boji mothage doeeotseoyo.
examples.en: The tickets sold out, so I ended up not being able to see that concert.

title: ~게 하다 [ge hada] (Make/let someone do)
short_explanation: This is a way to indicate that you are making or allowing someone else to do something.
long_explanation: `~게 하다 [ge hada]` is a Korean grammar form used to express that someone is making or allowing someone else to do something. This structure often indicates persuading, ordering, permitting, or causing an action to happen. In English, it can be similar to 'make someone do something' or 'let someone do something'.

examples.kr: 엄마는 저를 매일 한 시간 동안 피아노를 연습하게 했어요.
examples.romaji: Eommaneun jeoreul maeil han sigan dongan pianoreul yeonseuphage haesseoyo.
examples.en: My mother made me practice the piano for an hour every day.

examples.kr: 선생님은 학생들이 공부하게 했는데, 그것이 좋은 성적을 받을 수 있는 유일한 방법이라고 생각했어요.
examples.romaji: Seonsaengnimeun hagsaengdeuri gongbu hage haessneunde, geugeosi joheun seongjeogeul badeul su inneun yuilhan bangbeobilago saenggakhaesseoyo.
examples.en: The teacher made the students study, thinking that it was the only way to get good grades.

examples.kr: 아버지는 저를 이 일에 대해 생각하게 했습니다. 이 일은 중요한 결정을 필요로 하고 있었습니다.
examples.romaji: Abeojineun jeoreul i ire daehae saenggakhage haesseumnida. I ireun jungyohan gyeoljeongeul piryoro hago isseossseumnida.
examples.en: My father made me think about this matter. It required an important decision.

examples.kr: 나는 내 친구에게 ‘네가 서울에 간다’고 말하게 했습니다. 그는 그 정보를 알아야 했습니다.
examples.romaji: Naneun nae chingu-ege ‘nega Seoure ganda’go malhage haesseumnida. Geuneun geu jeongboreul al-aya haesseumnida.
examples.en: I made my friend say that he is going to Seoul. He needed to know that information.

title: ~고 싶다 [go sipda] (Want to do)
short_explanation: Used to express a desire or a wish.
long_explanation: '~고 싶다 [go sipda]' is a grammatical form used to express a person's desire or wish to do something in Korean. It's often used with verbs when expressing “I want to…” or “I would like to….” Typically, it’s best used for your own desires rather than attributing desires to others (in which case different expressions are often used).

examples.kr: 저는 한국어 노래를 듣고 싶어요, 그러니까 한국어 노래를 틀어주세요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hangugeo noraereul deutgo sipeoyo, geureonikka hangugeo noraereul teureojuseyo.
examples.en: I want to listen to Korean songs, so please play some.

examples.kr: 방학에는 친구들과 여행 가고 싶어요.
examples.romaji: Banghak-eneun chingudeulgwa yeohaeng gago sipeoyo.
examples.en: I want to go on a trip with my friends during the holidays.

examples.kr: 그녀에게 한국어를 가르치고 싶어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoege hangugeoreul gareuchigo sipeoyo.
examples.en: I want to teach her Korean.

examples.kr: 맛있는 음식을 만들고 싶어서 요리 수업을 듣고 싶어요.
examples.romaji: Masinneun eumsigeul mandeulgo sipeoseo yori sueobeul deutgo sipeoyo.
examples.en: I want to make delicious food, so I want to take cooking classes.

title: ~기 전에 [gi jeone] (Before doing)
short_explanation: Used to express 'before doing something'.
long_explanation: '~기 전에 [gi jeone]' is a grammatical structure in Korean used to indicate that one action happens before another, essentially meaning 'before doing something'. It describes the chronological order in which actions occur, whether in the past, present, or future.

examples.kr: 저는 학교에 가기 전에 항상 아침 식사를 합니다.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hakgyoe gagi jeone hangsang achim siksareul hamnida.
examples.en: I always have breakfast before going to school.

examples.kr: 출발하기 전에 자세히 계획을 세우는 것이 중요합니다.
examples.romaji: Chulbalhagi jeone jasehi gyehoeg-eul seuneun geosi jungyohamnida.
examples.en: It's important to plan carefully before leaving.

examples.kr: 제가 카페에 가기 전에 당신의 주문을 알려주십시오.
examples.romaji: Jega kapee gagi jeone dangsinui jumuneul allyeojusipsio.
examples.en: Let me know your order before I go to the cafe.

examples.kr: 시험을 치르기 전에 그 주제에 대해 충분히 공부를 해야 합니다.
examples.romaji: Siheomeul chireugi jeone geu jujee daehae chungbunhi gongbureul haeya hamnida.
examples.en: Before taking the test, you must study enough about that topic.

title: ~기 때문에 [gi ttaemune] (Because of doing)
short_explanation: Used to express a reason or cause; 'because (of doing)'.
long_explanation: '기 때문에 [gi ttaemune]' is a grammar point used in Korean to express a reason or cause related to an action, equivalent to 'because (of doing)' in English. This form uses the nominalizing suffix '기' plus '때문에' to explain why something happens, showing a cause-effect relationship.

examples.kr: 저는 공부하기 때문에 친구들과 놀러 갈 시간이 없어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun gongbuhagi ttaemune chingudeulgwa nolleo gal sigani eopseoyo.
examples.en: Because I study, I have no time to hang out with my friends.

examples.kr: 감기에 걸리기 때문에 학교에 가지 못했어요.
examples.romaji: Gamgie geolligi ttaemune hakgyoe gaji mothaesseoyo.
examples.en: I couldn't go to school because I caught a cold.

examples.kr: 많은 돈을 벌기 때문에 직장에 계속 나가고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Maneun doneul beolgi ttaemune jikjange gyesok nagago isseoyo.
examples.en: I keep going to work because I earn a lot of money.

examples.kr: 운동하기 때문에 건강해지고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Undonghagi ttaemune geonganghaejigo isseoyo.
examples.en: I'm getting healthier because of exercising.

title: ~기로 하다 [giro hada] (Decide to do)
short_explanation: Used to express making a decision or a plan to do something.
long_explanation: '~기로 하다' is used as Verb stem + 기로 하다 to express a decision or plan to do something. It often translates to 'decide to do' in English and is used when the speaker is stating what they (or someone) have decided, often as the result of a conversation or personal resolve.

examples.kr: 우리는 내일 오후에 만나기로 했어요. 그래서 내일 아침에 일어나서 준비해야 돼요.
examples.romaji: Urineun naeil ohue mannagiro haesseoyo. Geuraeseo naeil achime ileonaseo junbihaeya dwaeyo.
examples.en: We decided to meet tomorrow afternoon. So I have to wake up and get ready in the morning.

examples.kr: 저는 다음 주에 친구와 여행 가기로 했어요. 그래서 이번 주말에 가방을 싸야 돼요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun daeum jue chinguwa yeohaeng gagiro haesseoyo. Geuraeseo ibeon jumare gabangeul ssaya dwaeyo.
examples.en: I decided to go on a trip with a friend next week. So I have to pack my bag this weekend.

examples.kr: 최근에 너무 많이 먹어서 다이어트하기로 했어요. 그래서 오늘부터 식단을 조절하기로 했어요.
examples.romaji: Choegeneun neomu mani meogeoseo daieoteu haggiro haesseoyo. Geuraeseo oneulbuteo sikdaneul jojeolhaggiro haesseoyo.
examples.en: I ate too much recently, so I decided to go on a diet. So starting today, I decided to control my meal plan.

examples.kr: 시험 공부를 시작하기로 했어요. 그래서 오늘부터 매일 노트를 작성하고 싶어요.
examples.romaji: Siheom gongbureul sijakgiro haesseoyo. Geuraeseo oneulbuteo maeil noteureul jaksseonghago sipeoyo.
examples.en: I decided to start studying for the test. So from today, I want to write notes every day.

title: ~기 시작하다 [gi sijakhada] (Start to do)
short_explanation: Expresses the start or commencement of an action or event.
long_explanation: '~기 시작하다 [gi sijakhada]' is used to express the beginning of an action in Korean. By nominalizing a verb with '~기' and then using '시작하다 (to start)', you convey that the action has just begun or is beginning soon.

examples.kr: 날씨가 점점 따뜻해지면서 꽃들이 피기 시작했어요.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga jeomjeom ttatteut-haejimyeonseo kkotdeuri pigi sijakhaesseoyo.
examples.en: As the weather got warmer, the flowers started to bloom.

examples.kr: 학기가 시작되자마자 숙제를 하기 시작했어요.
examples.romaji: Hakgiga sijakdoejamaja sujereul hagi sijakhaesseoyo.
examples.en: As soon as the semester began, I started doing homework.

examples.kr: 그녀는 피아노를 치기 시작했습니다.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun pianoreul chigi sijakhaetsseumnida.
examples.en: She started playing the piano.

examples.kr: 친구들이 도착하자마자 파티가 시작됐어요.
examples.romaji: Chingudeuri dochakhajamaja patiga sijakdwaesseoyo.
examples.en: As soon as my friends arrived, the party started.

title: ~기는 하다 [gineun hada] (Indeed do, but...)
short_explanation: Used to emphasize or concede that one does something, often followed by a contrasting point.
long_explanation: '~기는 하다' attaches the nominalizer '~기' to a verb, followed by '는 하다'. It often indicates a concession or emphasis: “Yes, I do X (indeed), but...”. In many cases, it implies the action is done, yet not wholeheartedly, or a contrary result follows. It’s not limited to habitual actions, but more about emphasizing or conceding the fact that you do it.

examples.kr: 매일 아침에 영어를 공부하기는 하지만, 아직도 버벅거려요.
examples.romaji: Maeil achime yeongeoreul gongbuhagineun hajiman, ajikdo beobeokgeoryeoyo.
examples.en: I do study English every morning, but I still stumble over it.

examples.kr: 저는 주말에 책을 읽기는 하는데, 많은 시간을 할애하지는 않아요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun jumare chaegeul ilgineun haneunde, maneun siganeul halae-hajineun anhayo.
examples.en: I do read books on the weekends, but I don't devote a lot of time to it.

examples.kr: 요리를 하기는 하지만, 제 입맛에 꼭 맞지는 않아요.
examples.romaji: Yorireul hagineun hajiman, je ipmate kkok majineun anhayo.
examples.en: I do cook, but it’s not exactly to my taste.

examples.kr: 운동을 하루에 한 시간씩 하기는 하는데, 아직도 체력이 부족해요.
examples.romaji: Undongeul harue han siganssik hagineun haneunde, ajikdo cheryeogi bujokaeyo.
examples.en: I do work out for an hour a day, but I'm still lacking in stamina.

title: ~는 대로 [neun daero] (As it is / Just as someone says)
short_explanation: '~는 대로' is used to state that something is done exactly as it is or as told/given.
long_explanation: The '~는 대로 [neun daero]' structure expresses doing something exactly in the manner stated or indicated, with no alteration. It can also be used when following instructions precisely or maintaining the original state/method.

examples.kr: 제가 말하는 대로 정확히 따라해 주세요. 그렇게 하면 실패할 가능성이 낮아질 거예요.
examples.romaji: Jega malhaneun daero jeonghwakhi ttarahae juseyo. Geureoke hamyeon silpaehal ganeungseongi najajil geoyeyo.
examples.en: Please follow exactly as I say. Doing so will lower the chance of failure.

examples.kr: 이 설명서에 적힌 대로 장난감을 조립하면 어려움 없이 완성할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: I seolmyeongseoe jeokhin daero jangnangameul joriphamyeon eoryeoum eopsi wanseonghal su isseoyo.
examples.en: If you assemble the toy as written in these instructions, you can finish it without difficulty.

examples.kr: 그는 부모님이 가르치는 대로 모든 것을 해왔고, 그 노력 덕분에 성공적인 삶을 살고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun bumonimi gareuchineun daero modeun geoseul haewatgo, geu noryeok deokbune seonggongjeogin salmeul salgo isseoyo.
examples.en: He has done everything the way his parents taught him, and thanks to that effort, he is living a successful life.

examples.kr: 음악을 들을 때는 가수가 부르는 대로 따라 부르는 게 제일 재미있어요.
examples.romaji: Eumageul deureul ttaeneun gasuga bureuneun daero ttara bureuneun ge jeil jaemiisseoyo.
examples.en: When listening to music, it’s most fun to sing along exactly the way the singer does.

title: ~는 바람에 [neun barame] (Because of / Due to)
short_explanation: Used when indicating the cause of a negative result or situation.
long_explanation: '~는 바람에 [neun barame]' literally means 'because of (this wind/event)' and is used to describe a reason or cause behind an unfortunate or negative outcome. It emphasizes that the cause led directly to some undesirable result.

examples.kr: 집에 늦게 도착하는 바람에 이른 아침 수업을 놓쳤어요.
examples.romaji: Jibe neujge dochakhaneun barame ireun achim sueobeul nohchyeosseoyo.
examples.en: Because I arrived home late, I missed the early morning class.

examples.kr: 그녀가 파티에 오지 않는 바람에 기분이 좋지 않았어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga patie oji anneun barame gibuni jotji anasseoyo.
examples.en: I felt bad because she didn’t come to the party.

examples.kr: 비가 오는 바람에 피크닉을 취소했어요.
examples.romaji: Biga oneun barame pikeunikeul chwisohaesseoyo.
examples.en: I had to cancel the picnic because it rained.

examples.kr: 전화를 받지 못한 바람에 중요한 미팅을 놓쳤어요.
examples.romaji: Jeonhwareul badji motan barame jungyohan mitingeul nohchyeosseoyo.
examples.en: Because I couldn't answer the phone, I missed an important meeting.

title: ~는데 [neunde] (But / however / and)
short_explanation: Used to express contrast, provide background, or connect clauses. Often means 'but' or 'however'.
long_explanation: '~는데 [neunde]' can serve various functions: showing contrast (similar to 'but'), providing background information before another statement, or simply linking clauses. It is one of the most common connective endings in Korean, and nuance depends on context.

examples.kr: 저는 밥을 많이 먹었는데 아직도 배가 고파요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun babeul mani meogeonneunde ajikdo baega gopayo.
examples.en: I ate a lot, but I'm still hungry.

examples.kr: 제 친구는 항상 늦게 잠에 드는데 항상 일찍 일어나요.
examples.romaji: Je chinguneun hangsang neutge jame deuneunde hangsang iljjik ileonayo.
examples.en: My friend always goes to bed late, but somehow always wakes up early.

examples.kr: 요즘 날씨가 추운데 눈이 안 와서 아쉬워요.
examples.romaji: Yojum nalssiga chuunde nuni an waseo aswiwoyo.
examples.en: The weather is cold these days, but it's a shame that it's not snowing.

examples.kr: 영화 보러 갔는데 표가 매진되어서 못 봤어요.
examples.romaji: Yeonghwa boreo ganneunde pyoga maejindoeeoseo mot bwasseoyo.
examples.en: I went to see a movie, but the tickets were sold out, so I couldn’t watch it.

title: ~는지 모르다 [neunji moreuda] (Don't know if)
short_explanation: It is used when the speaker is unsure about a situation or fact.
long_explanation: '~는지 모르다' is a form used to express uncertainty or lack of knowledge about something in Korean. It corresponds to the English 'do not know if'. This construction is used when the speaker does not know whether something happened, exists, or is true. The verb or adjective in front of '는지 모르다' should be in its adnominal form.
formation: Verb-는지 모르다 / Verb-ㄴ(은)지 모르다 / Adjective-는지 모르다

examples.kr: 그가 오늘 학교에 올 것인지 모르겠어요.
examples.romaji: Geuga oneul hakgyoe ol geot-inji moreugesseoyo.
examples.en: I don't know if he's coming to school today.

examples.kr: 그녀가 어떤 옷을 입을지 모르겠어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga eotteon oseul ibeulji moreugesseoyo.
examples.en: I don't know what kind of clothes she will wear.

examples.kr: 그가 이 이야기를 들었는지 모릅니다.
examples.romaji: Geuga i iyagireul deureonneunji moreumnida.
examples.en: I don't know if he heard this story.

examples.kr: 우리 친구가 이곳에서 행복할지 모르겠어요.
examples.romaji: Uri chinguga igoseseo haengbokhalji moreugesseoyo.
examples.en: I don't know if our friend will be happy here.

title: ~는지 알다 [neunji alda] (Know if)
short_explanation: Used to express 'know if' or 'know whether'.
long_explanation: '~는지 알다 [neunji alda]' is used to express the concept of knowing if something is the case or not. It’s often used when conveying what someone knows or needs to find out about a situation, event, or fact.

examples.kr: 그가 내 말을 이해하는지 알 수 없어요.
examples.romaji: Geuga nae mareul ihaehaneunji al su eopseoyo.
examples.en: I can't tell if he understands my words.

examples.kr: 그녀가 결정을 내렸는지 알고 싶어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga gyeoljeongeul naeryeonneunji algo sipeoyo.
examples.en: I want to know if she has made a decision.

examples.kr: 우리가 다음 주에 만날 수 있는지 알아야 해요.
examples.romaji: Uriga daeum jue mannal su issneunji al-aya haeyo.
examples.en: We need to find out if we can meet next week.

examples.kr: 학생들이 문제를 해결하는지 알기 위해 선생님들이 항상 확인합니다.
examples.romaji: Haksaengdeuri munjeleul haegyeolhaneunji algi wihae seonsaengnimdeuri hangsang hwaginhapnida.
examples.en: Teachers always check to see if the students are solving the problem.

title: ~마다 [mada] (Every)
short_explanation: Used to express a recurring or regular occurrence: 'every'.
long_explanation: '~마다 [mada]' is a postposition in Korean used to express repetition or a recurring pattern. It corresponds to 'every' in English, indicating that something happens each time, every instance, or every unit of the specified noun.

examples.kr: 저는 매일 아침마다 일찍 일어나서 운동을 합니다.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun maeil achimmada iljjik ileonaseo undongeul hamnida.
examples.en: I wake up early and exercise every morning.

examples.kr: 여행을 갈 때마다 새로운 사람들을 만나서 매우 흥미로워요.
examples.romaji: Yeohaengeul gal ttaemada saeroun saramdeureul mannaseo maeu heungmirowoyo.
examples.en: Whenever I go traveling, I meet new people and it's very interesting.

examples.kr: 테스트가 끝날 때마다 휴식을 조금씩 취합니다.
examples.romaji: Testeuga kkeutnal ttaemada hyusigeul jogeumssik chwihabnida.
examples.en: I take a bit of a rest every time a test ends.

examples.kr: 일주일마다 한국어를 공부하기 위해 도서관에 갑니다.
examples.romaji: Iljuilmada hangugeoreul gongbuhagi wihae doseogwane gamnida.
examples.en: I go to the library to study Korean every week.

title: ~부터 ~까지 [buteo ~ kkaji] (From ~ to ~)
short_explanation: Used to express the beginning and end of a range in time, space, or action.
long_explanation: '~부터 ~까지 [buteo ~ kkaji]' is used to indicate the starting point and ending point of an action, period, or location. It translates to 'from ~ to ~' in English and can be used for time, place, numbers, or other continuous ranges.
formation: Starting point + 부터 + End point + 까지

examples.kr: 우리는 월요일부터 금요일까지 일해요.
examples.romaji: Urineun wolyoilbuteo geumyoilkkaji ilhaeyo.
examples.en: We work from Monday to Friday.

examples.kr: 점심시간은 오후 12시부터 1시까지예요.
examples.romaji: Jeomsimsiganeun ohu yeoldusi-buteo han si-kkaji yeyo.
examples.en: Lunch time is from 12 p.m. to 1 p.m.

examples.kr: 서울부터 부산까지 기차로 얼마나 걸리나요?
examples.romaji: Seoulbuteo Busankkaji gicharo eolmana geollinayo?
examples.en: How long does it take from Seoul to Busan by train?

examples.kr: 나는 한국어를 공부하기 시작했을 때부터 지금까지 많이 발전했어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun hangugeoreul gongbu hagi sijakhaesseul ttaebuteo jigeumkkaji mani baljeonhaesseoyo.
examples.en: I have improved a lot from when I started studying Korean until now.

title: ~아/어/여 보이다 [a/eo/yeo boida] (Seems, looks like)
short_explanation: Used to express that something appears or seems a certain way from the speaker’s perspective.
long_explanation: The grammar '~아/어/여 보이다' is used to indicate that someone or something appears, looks, or seems a certain way based on the speaker’s perception. It can be translated as 'seems' or 'looks like' in English. It implies that the statement is an inference or impression, not an absolute fact.

examples.kr: 그 사람은 행복해 보여서 다른 사람들도 기분이 좋아지잖아요.
examples.romaji: Geu saram-eun haengbokhae boyeoseo dareun saramdeuldo gibuni jo-ajijjanayo.
examples.en: That person looks happy, so it makes other people feel good too.

examples.kr: 이 음식은 맛있어 보이지만 실제로는 좀 짰어요.
examples.romaji: I eumsigeun masisseo boijiman siljero-neun jom jjasseoyo.
examples.en: This food looks tasty, but it was actually a bit salty.

examples.kr: 그 남자는 항상 기분이 나쁘게 보이는데 무슨 문제가 있나요?
examples.romaji: Geu namjaneun hangsang gibuni nappeuge boineunde museun munjega issnayo?
examples.en: That man always looks upset; is there some problem?

examples.kr: 이 옷은 사진에서 볼 땐 예뻤는데, 실제로 보니까 그저 그래 보여요.
examples.romaji: I oseun sajin-eseo bol ttaen yeppeonneunde, siljero bonikka geujeo geurae boyeoyo.
examples.en: This outfit looked pretty in the photos, but in reality, it just looks so-so.

title: ~아/어/여 주다 [a/eo/yeo juda] (Do something for someone)
short_explanation: Used to express the action of doing something for someone’s benefit.
long_explanation: The '~아/어/여 주다 [a/eo/yeo juda]' form is used in Korean to express doing something for someone else. It is often used to show that the speaker (or subject) is performing an action as a favor, courtesy, or service to another person. In requests, it can also soften the tone, implying you want someone to do something for you.

examples.kr: 피곤해서 그럼 내가 그 숙제를 해 줄게.
examples.romaji: Pigonsaeseo geureom naega geu sukjereul hae julge.
examples.en: You look tired, so I'll do your homework for you.

examples.kr: 걱정하지 마세요, 우리 아빠가 우리를 위해 보호해 줄 거예요.
examples.romaji: Geokjeonghaji maseyo, uri appaga urireul wihae bohohae jul geoyeyo.
examples.en: Don't worry; our dad will protect us.

examples.kr: 집에 돌아가는 길에 아빠가 택시를 잡아 주었어요.
examples.romaji: Jibe doraganeun gire appaga taeksireul jaba jueosseoyo.
examples.en: On the way home, my dad caught a taxi for us.

examples.kr: 나는 어머니에게 저녁 식사를 만들어 주었어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun eomeoni-ege jeonyeok siksareul mandeureo jueosseoyo.
examples.en: I made dinner for my mother.

title: ~아/어/여야만 하다 [a/eo/yeoyaman hada] (Have to do)
short_explanation: This grammar point expresses necessity or obligation: 'must', 'have to'.
long_explanation: The phrase '~아/어/여야만 하다 [a/eo/yeoyaman hada]' indicates that someone must or has to do something. It closely corresponds to 'have to' or 'must' in English. The verb stem combines with '아/어/여야만 하다', depending on the final vowel of the verb.
formation: Verb stem + 아야만 하다 / 어야만 하다 / 여야만 하다

examples.kr: 모든 학생들은 시험을 준비해야만 해요. 그렇지 않으면 실패할 것입니다.
examples.romaji: Modeun haksaengdeureun siheomeul junbihaeyaman haeyo. Geureohji anheumyeon silpaehal geosimnida.
examples.en: All students have to prepare for the exam; otherwise, they will fail.

examples.kr: 지금 당장 나가야만 해요. 만약 늦으면 비행기를 놓칠 것입니다.
examples.romaji: Jigeum dangjang nagayaman haeyo. Manyak neujmyeon bihaenggireul nochil geosimnida.
examples.en: I have to leave right now. If I'm late, I'll miss the plane.

examples.kr: 너는 이 일을 마무리해야만 집에 갈 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Neoneun i ireul mamurihayaman jibe gal su isseoyo.
examples.en: You have to finish this work in order to go home.

examples.kr: 우리는 매일 아침 스트레칭을 해야만 해요. 건강을 유지하기 위해서입니다.
examples.romaji: Urineun maeil achim seuteurechingeul haeyaman haeyo. Geongangeul yujihagi wihaeseoimnida.
examples.en: We have to stretch every morning to maintain our health.

title: ~아/어/여도 되다 [a/eo/yeodo doeda] (Is it okay to ~ / May I ~)
short_explanation: Used to ask or state permission to do something.
long_explanation: '~아/어/여도 되다 [a/eo/yeodo doeda]' is a Korean grammar pattern used to ask for or give permission. In questions, it means 'May I...?' or 'Is it okay to...?' In statements, it affirms that the action is permitted: 'You can...' or 'It’s okay to...'

examples.kr: 저는 이 자리에 앉아도 되나요? 다른 사람이 예약하지 않았을 경우에만 가능해요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun i jarie anjado doenayo? Dareun sarami yeyakhaji anhasseul gyeongueman ganeunghaeyo.
examples.en: Can I sit in this seat? It’s only possible if nobody else has reserved it.

examples.kr: 내일 포토샵을 사용해도 돼요? 제 프로젝트에 필요하거든요.
examples.romaji: Naeil potosyapeul sayonghaedo dwaeyo? Je peurojekteue piryohageodeunyo.
examples.en: Can I use Photoshop tomorrow? I need it for my project.

examples.kr: 크게 음악을 들어도 되는 곳이 있나요? 록 음악을 좋아해서요.
examples.romaji: Keuge eumageul deureodo doeneun gosi issnayo? Rok eumageul joahaeseoyo.
examples.en: Is there a place where I can listen to loud music? I like rock music.

examples.kr: 나는 비가 와도 축구를 해도 돼요. 비를 너무 좋아하거든요.
examples.romaji: Naneun biga wado chukgureul haedo dwaeyo. Bireul neomu joahageodeunyo.
examples.en: I can play soccer even if it rains because I really like the rain.

title: ~아/어/여서는 안 되다 [a/eo/yeoseoneun an doeda] (Must not)
short_explanation: Indicates prohibition or that one must not do something.
long_explanation: '~아/어/여서는 안 되다' explicitly expresses that something must not be done. It is often translated as 'You must not...' or 'It's not allowed to...'. It follows the verb stem plus '아/어/여서' + '는 안 되다'.
formation: Verb stem + 아/어/여 + 서는 안 되다

examples.kr: 이 표지판을 보면, 여기에서 담배를 피워서는 안 돼요.
examples.romaji: I pyojipaneul bomyeon, yeogiseo dambaereul piwoseoneun an dwaeyo.
examples.en: Looking at this sign, you must not smoke here.

examples.kr: 우리는 건강을 소홀히 해서는 안 됩니다.
examples.romaji: Urineun geongangeul soholhi haeseoneun an doemnida.
examples.en: We must not neglect our health.

examples.kr: 이 작업은 정밀하게 해야 해서, 정신없이 해서는 안 돼요.
examples.romaji: I jageobeun jeongmilhage haeya haeseo, jeongsineopsi haeseoneun an dwaeyo.
examples.en: You must do this job meticulously, so you must not do it carelessly.

examples.kr: 듣기 테스트 때문에 핸드폰을 켜서는 안 된다고 강조했습니다.
examples.romaji: Deudgi teseuteu ttaemune haendeuponeul kyeoseoneun an doendago gangjohaetsseumnida.
examples.en: I emphasized that you must not turn on your phone during the listening test.

title: ~아/어서 [a/eo-seo] (Because, so)
short_explanation: Used to express cause and effect, or reason and result. Can also indicate a sequence ('after').
long_explanation: The '~아/어서 [a/eo-seo]' form is used in Korean to show a cause-effect or reason-result relationship. It can also have a temporal meaning ('after doing something, then...'). For cause and effect, it is similar to 'because' or 'so' in English.

examples.kr: 오늘은 일이 많아서 학교에 가지 못했어요.
examples.romaji: Oneureun iri manaseo hakgyoe gaji mothaesseoyo.
examples.en: I couldn't go to school today because I had a lot of work.

examples.kr: 방이 추워서 옷을 더 많이 입었어요.
examples.romaji: Bangi chuwoseo oseul deo mani ibeosseoyo.
examples.en: I wore more clothes because the room was cold.

examples.kr: 그는 운동을 많이 해서 건강한 몸을 유지하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun undongeul mani haeseo geonganghan momeul yujihago isseoyo.
examples.en: He maintains a healthy body because he exercises a lot.

examples.kr: 키가 작아서 외투를 사기 어려웠어요.
examples.romaji: Kiga jakaseo oetureul sagi eoryeowosseoyo.
examples.en: I had a hard time buying a coat because I'm short.

title: ~았/었으면 좋겠다 [at/eosseumyeon joketda] (I wish/hope)
short_explanation: Used to express a desire for something to happen; equivalent to 'I wish/hope' in English.
long_explanation: '~았/었으면 좋겠다 [at/eosseumyeon joketda]' is a Korean grammar form used to express a wish or hope for a certain event or situation to happen. It combines a past-tense marker (~았/었) with the conditional '면' and '좋겠다' (hope). The meaning is similar to 'I wish' or 'I hope' in English, conveying a desire for something that is not currently the case, but which the speaker wishes would be or become so.

examples.kr: 시간이 많았으면 좋겠어요, 그럼 더 많은 책을 읽을 수 있었을 텐데.
examples.romaji: Sigani manasseumyeon jokesseoyo, geureom deo manheun chaegeul ilgul su isseosseul tende.
examples.en: I wish I had more time; then I could have read more books.

examples.kr: 내일 비가 왔으면 좋겠어요, 그래야 우리는 더 시원하게 쉴 수 있을 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Naeil biga wasseumyeon jokesseoyo, geuraeya urineun deo siwonhage swil su isseul geot gatayo.
examples.en: I hope it rains tomorrow, so we can relax more comfortably.

examples.kr: 그녀가 내 말을 더 이해했으면 좋겠다. 그러면 서로의 의견을 더 잘 나눌 수 있을 거예요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga nae mareul deo ihaehaesseumyeon joketda. Geureomyeon seoroui uigyeoneul deo jal nanul su isseul geoyeyo.
examples.en: I wish she understood me better; then we could share each other’s opinions more effectively.

examples.kr: 이번 주말에 날씨가 좋았으면 좋겠어요, 그럼 피크닉 갈 수 있을 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Ibeon jumare nalssiga johasseumyeon jokesseoyo, geureom piknik gal su isseul geot gatayo.
examples.en: I hope the weather is good this weekend, then we can probably go on a picnic.

title: ~어/아야 하다 [eo/ayahada] (Have to, should)
short_explanation: Used to express obligation, necessity, or compulsion—'have to', 'should'.
long_explanation: '~어/아야 하다 [eo/ayahada]' is used in Korean to express obligation, necessity, or compulsion, similar to 'have to' or 'should' in English. Depending on the final vowel of the verb stem, you use '아야 하다' (if the final vowel is ㅏ or ㅗ) or '어야 하다' (otherwise). This indicates that performing the verb's action is required or expected.

examples.kr: 내일 시험이 있으니까 오늘 밤에 공부해야 합니다.
examples.romaji: Naeil siheomi isseunikka oneul bame gongbuhaeya hamnida.
examples.en: I have to study tonight because I have an exam tomorrow.

examples.kr: 우리는 이번 주말에 집을 청소해야 해요.
examples.romaji: Urineun ibeon jumare jibeul cheongsohaeya haeyo.
examples.en: We have to clean the house this weekend.

examples.kr: 네가 감기에 걸렸으니까 약을 먹어야 하겠어요.
examples.romaji: Nega gamgigeollyeosseunikka yageul meogeoya hagesseoyo.
examples.en: Since you caught a cold, you should take some medicine.

examples.kr: 일찍 일어나야 해서 얼른 잠에 들어야 해요.
examples.romaji: Iljjik ileonaya haeseo eolleun jame deureoya haeyo.
examples.en: I have to get up early, so I should go to sleep quickly.

title: ~어/아도 [eo/ado] (Even if)
short_explanation: Used to express 'even if,' indicating a conditional situation or assumption.
long_explanation: '~어/아도 [eo/ado]' is a conjunctive ending in Korean meaning 'even if' or 'although.' It sets up a hypothetical or assumed condition, and states what happens despite that condition. The choice of '어' or '아' depends on the final vowel of the preceding verb stem, following typical Korean conjugation rules.

examples.kr: 비가 오더라도 저는 계속 걸어갈 거예요. 그게 제일 빠른 방법이거든요.
examples.romaji: Biga odeorado jeoneun gyesok georeogal geoyeyo. Geuge jeil ppareun bangbeobigodeunyo.
examples.en: Even if it rains, I will keep walking because that’s the fastest way.

examples.kr: 피곤하다고 아무리 말해도 저는 계속 일해야 해요. 이 일을 끝내야 하거든요.
examples.romaji: Pigonhadago amuri malhaedo jeoneun gyesok ilhaeya haeyo. I ireul kkeutnaeya hageodeunyo.
examples.en: Even if I say I'm tired, I must keep working, because I have to finish this job.

examples.kr: 어려운 문제라도 저는 포기하지 않고 계속 시도할 거예요. 저는 도전을 좋아하거든요.
examples.romaji: Eoryeoun munjerado jeoneun pogihaji anhgo gyesok sidohal geoyeyo. Jeoneun dojeoneul joahageodeunyo.
examples.en: Even if the problem is difficult, I won't give up and will keep trying, because I like challenges.

examples.kr: 시험 결과가 좋지 않아도 저는 분발하겠어요. 실패는 성공의 어머니라고 생각해요.
examples.romaji: Siheom gyeolgwaga johji anhado jeoneun bunbalhagess-eoyo. Silpaeneun seonggongui eomeonirago saenggakhaeyo.
examples.en: Even if the test results aren't good, I'll try harder. I believe failure is the mother of success.

title: ~어/아 버리다 [eo/a beorida] (Regretfully, completely)
short_explanation: Used to emphasize that an action is completed, often with regret or an unintended outcome.
long_explanation: '~어/아 버리다 [eo/a beorida]' is a verb ending that highlights the completion of an action, frequently carrying a feeling of regret, surprise, or finality. It often implies that the result was unintended or that the speaker wishes it had not happened.

examples.kr: 제가 중요한 출장을 놓쳐 버렸어요, 그래서 사장님께 혼이 났어요.
examples.romaji: Jega jungyohan chuljangeul nohchyeo beoryeosseoyo, geuraeseo sajangnimkke honi nasseoyo.
examples.en: I regretfully missed an important business trip, so my boss scolded me.

examples.kr: 친구가 제 가방을 다쳐 버렸어요, 그래서 안에 있던 물건들이 다 쏟아졌어요.
examples.romaji: Chinguga je gabangeul dachyeo beoryeosseoyo, geuraeseo ane itdeon mulgeondeuri da ssodajyeosseoyo.
examples.en: My friend ended up damaging my bag, and everything inside spilled out.

examples.kr: 브레이크를 밟지 않으면 차가 충돌해 버려서 모두 다칠 수도 있어요.
examples.romaji: Beureikeureul balpji anheumyeon chaga chungdolhae beoryeoseo modu dachil sudo isseoyo.
examples.en: If you don’t step on the brake, the car could crash, and everyone might get hurt.

examples.kr: 저도 모르게 그 말을 들어 버렸어요, 그래서 기분이 아주 안 좋아졌어요.
examples.romaji: Jeodo moreuge geu mareul deureo beoryeosseoyo, geuraeseo gibuni aju an joajyeosseoyo.
examples.en: I unintentionally overheard those words, and it really ruined my mood.

title: ~으면/면 [eumyeon/myeon] (If, when)
short_explanation: Used to express conditions or hypothetical situations: 'if' or 'when'.
long_explanation: '~으면/면 [eumyeon/myeon]' is used in Korean to express a condition or a hypothetical scenario, akin to 'if' or 'when' in English. It generally indicates that the main clause is contingent upon the condition in the subordinate clause.

examples.kr: 비가 오면 우산을 가져와야 해요.
examples.romaji: Biga omyeon usaneul gajyeowaya haeyo.
examples.en: If it rains, you should bring an umbrella.

examples.kr: 시간이 있으면 책을 좀 더 읽어 보겠어요.
examples.romaji: Sigani isseumyeon chaegeul jom deo ilgeo bogesseoyo.
examples.en: If I have time, I will try to read more books.

examples.kr: 영화를 보면 이해가 더 쉬울 거예요.
examples.romaji: Yeonghwaleul bomyeon ihaega deo swiul geoyeyo.
examples.en: If you watch the movie, it will be easier to understand.

examples.kr: 날씨가 좋으면 나가서 산책하겠습니다.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga joh-eumyeon nagaseo sanchaekhagessseumnida.
examples.en: If the weather is nice, I will go out for a walk.

title: ~을/를 빼다 [eul/reul ppaeda] (Except for)
short_explanation: Used to mean 'except for' or 'excluding', showing an exclusion from a group or set.
long_explanation: '~을/를 빼다 [eul/reul ppaeda]' is used in Korean to indicate that something is excluded from a given group, set, or situation. It can be translated as 'except for' or 'aside from.'

examples.kr: 그는 아무것도 하지 않았어요, 그림 그리는 것을 빼고 말이죠.
examples.romaji: Geuneun amugeotdo haji anhasseoyo, geurim geurineun geoseul ppaego marijyo.
examples.en: He didn't do anything except for drawing pictures.

examples.kr: 모든 학생이 방과 후에 운동을 했어요, 제가 아팠던 것을 빼고 말이죠.
examples.romaji: Modeun haksaengi banggwa hue undongeul haesseoyo, jega apatteon geoseul ppaego marijyo.
examples.en: All the students exercised after school except for me, because I was sick.

examples.kr: 저는 모든 과일을 좋아해요, 체리를 빼고요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun modeun gwaireul joahaeyo, cherireul ppaego-yo.
examples.en: I like all fruits except for cherries.

examples.kr: 지금까지 모든 영화를 다 봤어요, 코미디를 빼고요.
examples.romaji: Jigeumkkaji modeun yeonghwareul da bwasseoyo, komidireul ppaegoyo.
examples.en: So far, I've watched every type of movie except comedies.

title: ~을/를 수 있다 [eul/reul su itda] (Can, possible)
short_explanation: Expresses the ability or possibility to perform an action: 'can', 'be able to'.
long_explanation: '~을/를 수 있다 [eul/reul su itda]' is used to indicate that the subject is capable of or that it is possible to perform the action of the verb. It is commonly translated as 'can' or 'be able to' in English.

examples.kr: 우리는 이 문제를 해결할 수 있어요. 모두 함께 협력하면 충분히 가능하다고 생각해요.
examples.romaji: Urineun i munjeleul haegyeolhal su isseoyo. Modu hamkke hyeomnyeokhamyeon chungbunhi ganeunghadago saenggakhaeyo.
examples.en: We can solve this problem. I believe it's totally possible if we all cooperate.

examples.kr: 나는 내일 그 회의에 참석할 수 있을 것 같아요, 다행히 다른 일정이 없거든요.
examples.romaji: Naneun naeil geu hoeuie chamseokhal su isseul geot gatayo, dahenghi dareun iljeongi eopgeodeunyo.
examples.en: I think I can attend that meeting tomorrow, fortunately I don’t have any other schedule.

examples.kr: 당신이 수영을 배우면 언젠가 자유자재로 수영할 수 있을 거예요, 노력하면 가능합니다.
examples.romaji: Dangshini suyeongeul baeumyeon eonjenga jayujajaero suyeonghal su isseul geoyeyo, noryeokhamyeon ganeunghamnida.
examples.en: If you learn how to swim, you'll be able to swim freely someday. If you work at it, it’s possible.

examples.kr: 그는 한국어를 열심히 공부하면 TOPIK 시험을 패스할 수 있을 것입니다, 그리고 꼭 성공할 거예요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun hangugeoreul yeolsimhi gongbuhamyeon TOPIK siheomeul paeseuhal su isseul geosimnida, geurigo ggok seonggonghal geoyeyo.
examples.en: If he studies Korean diligently, he will be able to pass the TOPIK exam, and he'll definitely succeed.

title: ~을/를 통해 [eul/reul tonghae] (Through, via)
short_explanation: Used to show the medium or channel through which something is done or achieved.
long_explanation: '~을/를 통해 [eul/reul tonghae]' indicates that something is accomplished, communicated, or obtained by means of a certain method, channel, or medium. It corresponds to 'through' or 'via' in English.

examples.kr: 저는 한국어를 드라마를 통해 배웠어요. 그래서 표현을 좀 더 자연스럽게 익혔어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hangugeoreul deuramareul tonghae baeweosseoyo. Geuraeseo pyohyeoneul jom deo jayeonseureopge ikhyeosseoyo.
examples.en: I learned Korean through dramas, so I picked up more natural expressions.

examples.kr: 우리는 이메일을 통해 회의 일정을 조정했어요. 시간 관리가 훨씬 효율적이더라고요.
examples.romaji: Urineun imeireul tonghae hoeui iljeongeul jojeonghaesseoyo. Sigan gwalliga hwolssin hyoyuljeogideoragoyo.
examples.en: We adjusted the meeting schedule via email. Time management was much more efficient that way.

examples.kr: 그는 음악을 통해 감정을 표현하곤 해요. 음악은 그에게 가장 좋은 소통 수단이에요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun eumageul tonghae gamjeongeul pyohyeonhagon haeyo. Eumageun geuege gajang jo-eun sotong sudanieyo.
examples.en: He often expresses his emotions through music. Music is the best communication method for him.

examples.kr: 사진을 통해 우리는 다른 사람들의 일상생활을 이해하고 공감할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Sajineul tonghae urineun dareun saramdeuri ilsaengsaenghwareul ihaehago gonggamhal su isseoyo.
examples.en: Through photos, we can understand and empathize with other people's daily lives.

title: ~을까 [eulkka] (Shall we?)
short_explanation: Used to make a suggestion or proposal—'Shall we?', 'How about...?'.
long_explanation: '~을까 [eulkka]' is used in Korean to propose an idea or action to someone, similar to asking 'Shall we...?' or 'How about...?' in English. It’s casual and frequently used among friends or peers.

examples.kr: 우리 이번 주말에 캠핑을 가볼까?
examples.romaji: Uri ibeon jumare kaemping-eul gabolkka?
examples.en: Shall we go camping this weekend?

examples.kr: 내일 영화를 볼까?
examples.romaji: Naeil yeonghwareul bolkka?
examples.en: Shall we watch a movie tomorrow?

examples.kr: 오늘 저녁에 식당에서 저녁을 먹을까?
examples.romaji: Oneul jeonyeoge sikdang-eseo jeonyeogeul meogeulkka?
examples.en: Shall we have dinner at a restaurant tonight?

examples.kr: 학원 끝나고 나서 같이 공부할까?
examples.romaji: Hakwon geutnago naseo gachi gongbuhalkka?
examples.en: Shall we study together after the academy?

title: ~을래 [eullae] (Want to)
short_explanation: Expresses the speaker’s intention or will, often in casual speech: 'want to'.
long_explanation: '~을래 [eullae]' is an informal Korean sentence ending that conveys the speaker’s desire or intention to do something. It also functions like a suggestion when speaking with friends or close acquaintances, and can be translated as 'I want to...' or 'I'm going to...'.

examples.kr: 나는 오늘 밤 영화 보러 갈래. 너도 같이 갈래?
examples.romaji: Naneun oneul bam yeonghwa boreo gallae. Neodo gachi gallae?
examples.en: I want to go watch a movie tonight. Do you want to come too?

examples.kr: 저는 집에서 저녁을 먹을래요. 외식하는 것보다 집밥이 더 좋아요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun jib-eseo jeonyeogeul meogeullae-yo. Oesikhaneun geotboda jibbab-i deo joayo.
examples.en: I want to eat dinner at home. I like home-cooked meals more than eating out.

examples.kr: 나는 이번 주말에 친구들과 등산 갈래. 좀 운동도 해야 할 것 같아서.
examples.romaji: Naneun ibeon jumare chingudeulgwa deungsan gallae. Jom undongdo haeya hal geot gataseo.
examples.en: I want to go hiking with friends this weekend. I feel like I need some exercise.

examples.kr: 나는 내일부터 다이어트를 시작할래. 최근에 살이 많이 찐 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Naneun naeilbuteo daieoteureul sijakhallae. Choegene sal-i mani jjin geot gatayo.
examples.en: I want to start a diet from tomorrow. I think I've gained some weight lately.

title: ~을지라도 [euljirado] (Even if)
short_explanation: Emphasizes that the main clause remains true regardless of the condition in the subordinate clause.
long_explanation: '~을지라도 [euljirado]' translates to 'even if' in English. It is used to specify that no matter the condition introduced by the subordinate clause, the main clause still holds. It emphasizes determination or inevitability despite obstacles.

examples.kr: 문제가 어려울지라도 포기하지 마세요. 결국에는 해결할 수 있을 거예요.
examples.romaji: Munjega eoryeouljirado pogihaji maseyo. Gyeolgugeneun haegyeolhal su isseul geoyeyo.
examples.en: Even if the problem is difficult, don’t give up. You’ll be able to solve it eventually.

examples.kr: 이 책이 비쌀지라도 꼭 필요해서 반드시 사야겠어요.
examples.romaji: I chaegi bissaljirado ggok piryohaseo bandeusi sayagesseoyo.
examples.en: Even if this book is expensive, I really need it, so I'll definitely buy it.

examples.kr: 시험이 어려울지라도 열심히 공부하면 분명 성과가 있을 거예요.
examples.romaji: Siheomi eoryeouljirado yeolsimhi gongbuhamyeon bunmyeong seonggwaga isseul geoyeyo.
examples.en: Even if the test is difficult, if you study hard, you’ll surely see results.

examples.kr: 날씨가 추울지라도 친구들과 약속이 있으니 꼭 나가야 해요.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga chuwuljirado chingudeulgwa yaksogi issni kkok nagaya haeyo.
examples.en: Even if the weather is cold, I have a promise with friends, so I must go out.

title: ~을지언정 [euljieonjeong] (Even if, even though)
short_explanation: Used to mean 'even if' or 'even though,' emphasizing a strong concession or unexpected contrast.
long_explanation: '~을지언정 [euljieonjeong]' is a Korean grammar structure that expresses a concession or contrast. It conveys the idea of 'even if' or 'even though.' Despite the condition stated, the speaker insists on or highlights another fact or determination. It emphasizes that regardless of the possible negative or contrasting scenario, something remains important or unchanged.

examples.kr: 시험에 떨어질지언정 목표를 향해 계속 노력하는 것이 중요합니다.
examples.romaji: Siheome tteoreojiljieonjeong mokpyoreul hyanghae gyesok noryeokhaneun geosi jungyohamnida.
examples.en: Even if you fail the exam, it's important to keep striving toward your goal.

examples.kr: 벌써 봄이 왔을지언정 아직 날씨가 많이 춥네요.
examples.romaji: Beolsseo bomi wasseuljieonjeong ajik nalssiga mani chumneyo.
examples.en: Even though spring has already come, the weather is still very cold.

examples.kr: 방이 클지언정 정리하지 않으면 엉망이 될 거예요.
examples.romaji: Bangi keuljieonjeong jeongrihaji anheumyeon eongmangi doel geoyeyo.
examples.en: Even if the room is big, if you don't tidy up, it will become a mess.

examples.kr: 그녀에게 전화할지언정 그녀가 받을지 안 받을지는 모르겠어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoege jeonhwahaljieonjeong geunyeoga badeulji an badeuljineun moreugesseoyo.
examples.en: Even if I call her, I don't know whether she'll answer or not.

title: ~이 되다 [i doeda] (Become)
short_explanation: Used to indicate a change or transformation: 'become'.
long_explanation: '~이 되다 [i doeda]' is a common expression in Korean indicating the transformation or shift from one state to another, often with nouns. It can refer to changes in jobs, positions, relationships, states, etc. It basically carries the meaning of 'become' in English when attached to a noun followed by '이'.

examples.kr: 가을이 되니까 날씨가 추워져서 니트웨어가 꼭 필요하다고 느끼게 돼요.
examples.romaji: Gaeuri doeni-kka nalssiga chuwojyeoseo niteuweoga kkok pilyohadago neukkige dwaeyo.
examples.en: As it becomes autumn and the weather gets colder, I feel the need for knitwear.

examples.kr: 학부생 때는 변호사가 되고 싶었는데, 대학원에서는 교수가 되고 싶다는 생각이 들었어요.
examples.romaji: Hakbusaeng ttaeneun byeonhosaga doego sipeonneunde, daehagwon-eseoneun gyosuga doego sipdaneun saenggagi deureosseoyo.
examples.en: When I was an undergraduate, I wanted to become a lawyer, but in graduate school, I began thinking I want to be a professor.

examples.kr: 친구들과 함께 공부를 하니까 점점 더 좋은 학생이 되고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Chingudeulgwa hamkke gongbureul hanikka jeomjeom deo joeun haksaeng-i doego isseoyo.
examples.en: Studying together with my friends, I am gradually becoming a better student.

examples.kr: 얼굴에 난 흠집이 결국 큰 흉터가 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Eolgure nan heumjibi gyeolguk keun hyungteoga doeeosseoyo.
examples.en: The scratch on my face ended up becoming a big scar.

title: ~이나 ~ [ina] (Either... or...)
short_explanation: Used to offer or list multiple options or possibilities, similar to 'either... or...'.
long_explanation: '~이나 ~' is used in Korean to give alternatives or options, much like 'either... or...' in English. It can introduce two or more nouns, verbs, or phrases. The construction often appears as 'Noun1 + 이나 + Noun2 + (하)나 + Verb/Adjective', offering multiple choices.

examples.kr: 우리는 주말에 영화를 보러 가거나, 집에서 게임이나 할 거예요.
examples.romaji: Urineun jumare yeonghwareul boreo gageona, jib-eseo geim-ina hal geoyeyo.
examples.en: We will either go watch a movie this weekend or just play games at home.

examples.kr: 커피나 차나 마시면서 좀 쉬고 싶어요.
examples.romaji: Keopina chana masimyeonseo jom swigo sipeoyo.
examples.en: I want to relax while having either coffee or tea.

examples.kr: 오늘이나 내일이나 아무 때나 괜찮아요.
examples.romaji: Oneulina naeilirina amu ttaena gwaenchanayo.
examples.en: Either today or tomorrow is fine with me.

examples.kr: 이번 달에는 여행을 가거나, 아니면 집에서 책이나 읽으면서 쉬려고 해요.
examples.romaji: Ibeon dal-eneun yeohaengeul gageona, animyeon jib-eseo chaeg-ina ilgeumyeonseo swiryeogo haeyo.
examples.en: This month, I plan to either go traveling or relax at home reading books.

title: ~이라도 [irado] (At least, even if)
short_explanation: Used to express 'at least' or 'even if it's just...', showing a minimal or second-best option.
long_explanation: '~이라도 [irado]' is used in Korean to indicate a compromise, lesser option, or minimal requirement. It often conveys 'at least' or 'even if it's only…'. It can suggest that the speaker would settle for something, even if it’s not ideal.

examples.kr: 이 비싼 가격에도 불구하고 저기 음식이라도 사 먹어야겠어요. 안 먹으면 힘이 없을 테니까요.
examples.romaji: I bissan gagyeogedo bulguhago jeogi eumsigirado sa meogeoyagesseoyo. An meogeumyeon himi eopseul tenikkayo.
examples.en: Even though it's expensive, I must at least buy that food over there. If I don’t eat, I’ll have no energy.

examples.kr: 오늘 일정이 아주 바쁘지만, 저녁이라도 제대로 먹어야 할 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Oneul iljeongi aju bappeujiman, jeonyeogirado jedaero meogeoya hal geot gatayo.
examples.en: My schedule is really busy today, but I should at least eat a proper dinner.

examples.kr: 그의 성격이 별로지만 일이라도 잘해서 팀에서 중요한 사람이에요.
examples.romaji: Geuui seonggyeogi byeollojiman irirado jalhaeseo tim-eseo jungyohan saram-ieyo.
examples.en: Even though his personality isn’t great, he’s good at his work, so he’s important to the team.

examples.kr: 시험이 어렵다고 해도 돌아가는 상황이라도 어느 정도 파악은 해야겠어요.
examples.romaji: Siheomi eoryeobdago haedo doraganeun sanghwangirado eoneu jeongdo paageun haeyagesseoyo.
examples.en: Even if they say the test is difficult, I should at least keep up with what’s going on.

title: ~이랑 [irang] (And, with)
short_explanation: Used to mean 'and' or 'with' when linking nouns in casual speech.
long_explanation: '~이랑 [irang]' is an informal connective in Korean, roughly equivalent to 'and' or 'with.' It can link people, objects, or concepts, and is very common in spoken language. It’s less formal than other conjunctions like '~하고' or '~와/과.'

examples.kr: 오늘 친구랑 영화를 보러 갔어요.
examples.romaji: Oneul chingurang yeonghwareul boreo gasseoyo.
examples.en: Today I went to watch a movie with a friend.

examples.kr: 저는 커피랑 케이크를 주문했어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun keopirang keikeureul jumunhaesseoyo.
examples.en: I ordered coffee and cake.

examples.kr: 언니랑 저는 같은 옷을 입었어요.
examples.romaji: Eonni-rang jeoneun gateun oseul ibeosseoyo.
examples.en: My older sister and I wore the same clothes.

examples.kr: 아빠랑 엄마는 서울에서 살고 계세요.
examples.romaji: Apparang eommaneun Seoureseo salgo gyeseyo.
examples.en: My dad and mom live in Seoul.

title: ~이래 [irae] (Since)
short_explanation: Used to mark the starting point of an event in the past and its continuation to the present: 'since'.
long_explanation: '~이래 [irae]' marks a starting point in the past from which a situation has continued until now. It’s similar to 'since' in English. It typically follows a verb in past tense that indicates when the action or event began.

examples.kr: 제가 태어난 이래 이렇게 추운 겨울은 처음이에요.
examples.romaji: Jega taeeonan irae ireoke chuun gyeoureun cheoeum-ieyo.
examples.en: This is the coldest winter I've experienced since I was born.

examples.kr: 그가 학교를 졸업한 이래로 처음 만났어요.
examples.romaji: Geuga hakgyoreul joleobhan iraero cheoeum mannasseoyo.
examples.en: This is the first time I’ve seen him since he graduated.

examples.kr: 이사 온 이래로 친구를 못 사귀어서 좀 외로워요.
examples.romaji: Isa on iraero chingureul mot sagwyeoseo jom oerowoyo.
examples.en: I've been a bit lonely since I moved here because I haven't made any friends.

examples.kr: 퇴근한 이래 계속 바빠서 쉬지 못했어요.
examples.romaji: Toegeunhan irae gyesok bappaseo swiji mothaesseoyo.
examples.en: Since I got off work, I’ve been busy and haven’t been able to rest.

title: ~이므로 [imyeo] (Because, so)
short_explanation: Used to indicate a reason or cause: 'because', 'so'.
long_explanation: '~이므로 [imyeo]' is a conjunctive form used in Korean to indicate cause or reason, roughly meaning 'because' or 'so.' It typically follows a noun, adjective, or verb, showing that the preceding clause is the reason for what follows.

examples.kr: 오늘 비가 오므로 우산을 가져왔어요.
examples.romaji: Oneul biga omuro usaneul gajyeowasseoyo.
examples.en: Because it’s raining today, I brought an umbrella.

examples.kr: 그녀는 좋은 성적을 받았으므로 모두가 놀랐어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun joheun seongjeogeul badasseumuro moduga nollasseoyo.
examples.en: Because she got such good grades, everyone was surprised.

examples.kr: 이 작업은 어렵므로 조심해서 해야 합니다.
examples.romaji: I jageobeun eoryeowumuro josimhaseo haeya hamnida.
examples.en: Because this work is difficult, you must do it carefully.

examples.kr: 상황이 심각하므로 내일로 치료를 미루지 마세요.
examples.romaji: Sanghwangi simgakhamuro naeillo chiryoreul miruji maseyo.
examples.en: Because the situation is serious, don’t postpone treatment until tomorrow.

title: ~이어서 [ieoseo] (And then, so) — (Using ~아/어서)
short_explanation: Often appears as ~아/어서 in modern usage to link clauses in sequence (and then) or cause/effect (so).
long_explanation: The expression '~이어서 [ieoseo]' can literally mean 'continuing on from that,' but in modern usage the closely related connectors '~아/어서' also cover 'and then' or 'so' functions in Korean. These examples show how one action or event naturally leads to another, or how one reason leads to a result.
formation: Action Verb + -아/어서 (depending on the verb stem’s final vowel)

examples.kr: 저는 오늘 일찍 집에 와서 책을 읽었어요. 그리고 나서 바로 잠들었어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun oneul iljjik jibe waseo chaeg-eul ilgeosseoyo. Geurigo naseo baro jamdeureosseoyo.
examples.en: I came home early today and read a book. Then I immediately fell asleep.

examples.kr: 오늘 아침에 비가 와서 나가기 힘들었고, 그래서 집에서 쉬었어요.
examples.romaji: Oneul achime biga waseo nagagi himdeureotgo, geuraeseo jibeseo swieosseoyo.
examples.en: It rained this morning, so it was hard to go out, so I rested at home.

examples.kr: 친구를 만나러 갔는데, 맛있는 음식을 같이 먹었어요.
examples.romaji: Chingureul mannareo ganneunde, masinneun eumsigeul gachi meogeosseoyo.
examples.en: I went to meet a friend, and we ate some delicious food together.

examples.kr: 고양이를 봤는데 너무 귀여워서 사진을 찍었어요.
examples.romaji: Goyangireul bwatneunde neomu gwiyeowoseo sajineul jjigeosseoyo.
examples.en: I saw a cat, and it was so cute that I took a photo.

title: ~이지만 [ijiman] (But, however)
short_explanation: Used to show contrast or contradiction between two clauses: 'but', 'however'.
long_explanation: '~이지만 [ijiman]' is a Korean conjunctive form meaning 'but' or 'however.' The clause before ~이지만 states a fact or quality, and the clause after it presents a contrasting or conflicting fact. This structure emphasizes the difference or contradiction between them.

examples.kr: 날씨가 정말 좋지만, 외출할 시간이 없어요.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga jeongmal jojiman, oechulhal sigani eopseoyo.
examples.en: The weather is really nice, but I have no time to go out.

examples.kr: 저는 피자를 좋아하지만, 다이어트 때문에 먹을 수 없어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun pijareul joahajiman, daieoteu ttaemune meogeul su eopseoyo.
examples.en: I like pizza, but I can't eat it because of my diet.

examples.kr: 이 노래는 유명하지만, 저는 별로 좋아하지 않아요.
examples.romaji: I noraeneun yumyeonghajiman, jeoneun byeollo joahaji anhayo.
examples.en: This song is famous, but I don't really like it.

examples.kr: 친구가 저에게 돈을 준다고 약속했지만, 아직 못 받았어요.
examples.romaji: Chinguga jeoege doneul jundago yaksokhaetjiman, ajik mot badasseoyo.
examples.en: My friend promised to give me money, but I still haven't received it.

title: ~인/는데 [in/neunde] (But, so)
short_explanation: Used to connect clauses, often expressing contrast, background information, or a reason/cause: 'but', 'so', 'however'.
long_explanation: '~인/는데' is a broad label for endings like '인데' (for nouns), '(으)ㄴ데' (for adjectives or past tense verbs), and '는데' (for action verbs). These endings connect two clauses and can imply various nuances such as contrast ('but', 'however'), reason/cause, or background information setting up a following statement. The exact meaning depends on context.

examples.kr: 오늘 날씨가 좋은데 외출하지 않을 것 같아요. 집에서 영화를 볼 거예요.
examples.romaji: Oneul nalssiga joeunde oechulhaji anheul geot gatayo. Jibeseo yeonghwareul bol geoyeyo.
examples.en: The weather is nice today, but I don't think I'll go out. I'll watch a movie at home.

examples.kr: 잠을 잘 수 있었는데 알람 소리 때문에 깼어요.
examples.romaji: Jameul jal su isseonneunde allam sori ttaemune kkaesseoyo.
examples.en: I could have slept well, but I woke up because of the alarm.

examples.kr: 저는 한국어를 배우고 있는데 발음이 어려워서 가끔 힘들어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hangugeoreul baeugo inneunde bareumi eoryeowoseo gakkeum himdeureoyo.
examples.en: I'm learning Korean, but the pronunciation is difficult, so sometimes it's tough.

examples.kr: 구직 심사가 어려웠는데, 다행히도 이 직업을 찾을 수 있었어요.
examples.romaji: Gujik simsaga eoryeowonneunde, Dahaenghido i jigeobeul chajeul su isseosseoyo.
examples.en: The job-hunting process was hard, but fortunately, I was able to find this job.

title: ~자 [ja] (Let's)
short_explanation: Used to suggest or propose an action: 'let's'.
long_explanation: '~자 [ja]' is attached to a verb stem to propose an action or suggest doing something together, similar to 'let's' in English. It's an informal form commonly used among friends or peers.

examples.kr: 우리 영화 보러 가자. 여기서 새로 나온 영화를 보고 싶어요.
examples.romaji: Uri yeonghwa boreo gaja. Yeogiseo saero naon yeonghwareul bogo sipeoyo.
examples.en: Let's go watch a movie. I want to see the new release here.

examples.kr: 밖에 날씨가 좋으니까 산책하러 가자.
examples.romaji: Bakke nalssiga joeunikka sanchaekhareo gaja.
examples.en: The weather is nice outside, let's go for a walk.

examples.kr: 지금부터 공부하자. 시험이 가까운데 아직 개념을 잘 모르겠어요.
examples.romaji: Jigeumbuteo gongbuhaja. Siheom-i gakkaunde ajik gaenyeomeul jal moreugesseoyo.
examples.en: Let's start studying now. The exam is near, and I still don't fully understand the concepts.

examples.kr: 점심을 맛있게 먹었으니까 잠깐 쉬자. 배가 너무 불러요.
examples.romaji: Jeomsimeul masitge meogeosseunikka jamkkan swija. Baega neomu bulleoyo.
examples.en: We had a delicious lunch, so let's take a break. I'm really full.

title: ~자마자 [jamaja] (As soon as)
short_explanation: Used to indicate that the second event happens immediately after the first event: 'as soon as'.
long_explanation: '~자마자 [jamaja]' means 'as soon as' in English, showing that one action or event happens directly after another with no delay. The action in the second clause occurs immediately after the action in the first clause.

examples.kr: 학교에 도착하자마자 친구를 만났어요. 아침에 너무 바빠서 전화도 못 했어요.
examples.romaji: Hakgyoe dochakhamaja chingureul mannasseoyo. Achime neomu bappaseo jeonhwado mot haesseoyo.
examples.en: As soon as I arrived at school, I met my friend. I was so busy in the morning that I couldn't even call.

examples.kr: 문을 열자마자 고양이가 밖으로 나갔어요. 결국 한참 동안 찾아야 했어요.
examples.romaji: Muneul yeoljamaja goyangiga bakk-euro nagasseoyo. Gyeolguk hancham dongan chajaya haesseoyo.
examples.en: As soon as I opened the door, the cat ran outside. I had to look for it for quite a while.

examples.kr: 비행기가 착륙하자마자 핸드폰을 켰어요. 중요한 전화가 올 줄 알았거든요.
examples.romaji: Bihaenggiga chakryukhamaja haendeuponeul kyeosseoyo. Jungyohan jeonhwaga ol jul aratgeodeunyo.
examples.en: As soon as the airplane landed, I turned on my phone. I expected an important call.

examples.kr: 집에 돌아오자마자 바로 샤워했어요. 오늘 날씨가 너무 더웠어요.
examples.romaji: Jibe doraojamaja baro syawohesseoyo. Oneul nalssiga neomu deowosseoyo.
examples.en: As soon as I got home, I took a shower right away. It was really hot today.

title: ~처럼 [cheoreom] (Like, as)
short_explanation: Used to express similarity or resemblance: 'like', 'as if'.
long_explanation: '~처럼 [cheoreom]' is a postposition in Korean that expresses similarity or comparison, often translating to 'like' or 'as if' in English. It can be used with both nouns and verb phrases to show that something acts or appears in a similar way to another thing.

examples.kr: 그의 눈은 별처럼 반짝반짝 빛나요.
examples.romaji: Geuui nuneun byeolcheoreom banjjakbanjjak bitnayo.
examples.en: His eyes shine like stars.

examples.kr: 우리 아버지는 늘 날개가 달린 말처럼 열심히 일해요.
examples.romaji: Uri abeojineun neul nalgaega dallin malcheoreom yeolsimhi ilhaeyo.
examples.en: My father always works hard, like a horse with wings.

examples.kr: 그녀는 물고기처럼 수영을 잘해요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun mulgogicheoreom suyeongeul jalhaeyo.
examples.en: She swims as well as a fish.

examples.kr: 오늘 하루 종일 나는 새처럼 자유롭게 돌아다녔어요.
examples.romaji: Oneul haru jongil naneun saecheoreom jayurobge doradanyeosseoyo.
examples.en: All day today, I roamed around freely like a bird.

title: ~쯤 [jjeum] (Around, about)
short_explanation: Used to indicate approximation in quantity, time, or degree: 'around', 'about'.
long_explanation: '쯤 [jjeum]' is a Korean particle that denotes an approximation or an estimated range of time, quantity, or degree. It is similar to 'around' or 'about' in English. You attach it after a noun indicating time, number, or quantity.

examples.kr: 시험이 어려우니까 하루에 3시간쯤 공부해야 해요.
examples.romaji: Siheomi eoryeounikka harue sam siganjjeum gongbuhaeya haeyo.
examples.en: Because the exam is difficult, you should study around three hours a day.

examples.kr: 저희 집에서 버스로 가면 약 20분쯤 걸릴 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Jeohui jipeseo beoseuro gamyeon yak isip bunjjeum geollil geot gatayo.
examples.en: If you take the bus from my house, it will take about 20 minutes.

examples.kr: 오늘 너무 더워서 온도가 30도쯤 될 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Oneul neomu deowoseo ondoga samsip dojjeum doel geot gatayo.
examples.en: It's so hot today that I think it's around 30 degrees.

examples.kr: 그 책을 다 읽으려면 일주일 정도쯤 걸릴 거예요.
examples.romaji: Geu chaekeul da ilgeuryeomyeon ilju-il jeongdojjeum geollil geoyeyo.
examples.en: It'll take about a week to finish reading that book.

title: ~지 않다 [ji anta] (Not)
short_explanation: Used to negate a verb or adjective: 'not'.
long_explanation: '~지 않다 [ji anta]' is a negative form in Korean that translates to 'not' in English. It is attached to the verb/adjective stem to negate the action or state. It can be used in both formal and informal contexts to express that something does not happen or is not the case.

examples.kr: 저는 이번 회의에 참석하지 않을 거예요. 그 시간에 다른 중요한 일이 있어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun ibeon hoeuie chamseokhaji aneul geoyeyo. Geu sigane dareun jungyohan iri isseoyo.
examples.en: I will not attend this meeting. I have another important matter at that time.

examples.kr: 우리 아빠는 담배를 피우지 않아요. 그래서 집 안 공기가 항상 신선해요.
examples.romaji: Uri appaneun dambereul piuji anhayo. Geuraeseo jib an gonggiga hangsang sinseonhaeyo.
examples.en: My father doesn’t smoke, so the air in our house is always fresh.

examples.kr: 그녀는 밝은 표정을 짓지 않아서 다른 사람들과 거리를 두는 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun balgeun pyojeongeul jitji anhaseo dareun saramdeulgwa georireul duneun geot gatayo.
examples.en: She doesn't wear a bright expression, so it seems like she keeps her distance from others.

examples.kr: 저는 육류를 먹지 않아요. 그래서 항상 채식 메뉴를 찾아요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun yukryureul meokji anhayo. Geuraeseo hangsang chaesik menyureul chajayo.
examples.en: I do not eat meat, so I always look for vegetarian options.

title: ~지만 [jiman] (But)
short_explanation: Used to express contrast or contradiction; 'but', 'however'.
long_explanation: '~지만 [jiman]' is a conjunction used in Korean to indicate a contrast or contradiction between two clauses. It carries the sense of 'but' or 'however' in English. The speaker presents a fact or situation, then adds a conflicting or contrasting fact following '~지만'.

examples.kr: 저는 아주 피곤하지만, 이 일을 끝내야 해서 계속해야 할 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun aju pigonhajiman, i ireul kkeunnaeya haeseo gyesokhaeya hal geot gatayo.
examples.en: I'm very tired, but I think I have to keep going because I have to finish this work.

examples.kr: 그 음식은 맛이 없지만 영양이 가득해서 먹어야 해요.
examples.romaji: Geu eumsigeun masi eopsjiman yeongangi gadeukhaeseo meogeoya haeyo.
examples.en: The food is not tasty, but I have to eat it because it's full of nutrients.

examples.kr: 여러분 중에는 문제가 어렵다고 느끼는 분도 있겠지만, 포기하면 안 돼요.
examples.romaji: Yeoreobun jungeneun munjega eoryeopdago neukkineun bundo itgetjiman, pogihamyeon an dwaeyo.
examples.en: Some of you might find the problem difficult, but you must not give up.

examples.kr: 그는 성격이 좋지만 명확히 의견을 말하는 것은 좀 어려워해요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun seonggyeogi johjiman myeonghwakhi uigyeoneul malhaneun geoseun jom eoryeowohaeyo.
examples.en: He has a good personality, but he finds it a bit difficult to express his opinions clearly.

title: ~지요/~죠 [jiyo/jyo] (Isn’t it?, right?)
short_explanation: Used to confirm or seek agreement; 'isn't it?', 'right?'
long_explanation: The endings '~지요/~죠 [jiyo/jyo]' are used to seek confirmation or agreement from the listener, similar to saying 'isn't it?' or 'right?' in English. They soften the statement and can function like a tag question. The form can be used in varying politeness levels, depending on the overall speech style.

examples.kr: 오늘 날씨가 좋아지요?
examples.romaji: Oneul nalssiga joajiyo?
examples.en: The weather is nice today, isn't it?

examples.kr: 우리는 같은 반에 있었지요?
examples.romaji: Urineun gateun bane isseotjiyo?
examples.en: We were in the same class, right?

examples.kr: 이 일을 끝내야겠죠?
examples.romaji: I ireul kkeutnaeyagetjyo?
examples.en: We have to finish this work, don't we?

examples.kr: 그 영화 정말 재미있었지요?
examples.romaji: Geu yeonghwa jeongmal jaemiisseotjiyo?
examples.en: That movie was really fun, wasn't it?

title: ~하고 [hago] (And, with)
short_explanation: Used to connect nouns ('and') or indicate 'with' someone/something.
long_explanation: '~하고 [hago]' is used in Korean to connect two nouns in the sense of 'and' or to indicate 'with' when paired with a verb. It's commonly used in spoken language and is a bit more informal than '~와/과'.
formation: Noun1 + 하고 + Noun2 / Noun + 하고 + Verb

examples.kr: 저는 커피하고 도넛을 주문했어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun keopi hago doneuteul jumunhaesseoyo.
examples.en: I ordered coffee and doughnuts.

examples.kr: 우리는 함께 하고 이야기를 나누며 즐거운 시간을 보냈어요.
examples.romaji: Urineun hamkke hago iyagireul nanumyeo jeulgeoun siganeul bonaesseoyo.
examples.en: We spent an enjoyable time together, talking and hanging out.

examples.kr: 나는 딸기하고 바나나를 믹서에 넣어 스무디를 만들었어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun ttalgihago bananareul mikseo-e neoeo seumudireul mandeuleosseoyo.
examples.en: I put strawberries and bananas in a blender and made a smoothie.

examples.kr: 그는 친구하고 축구를 하려고 공원에 갔어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun chinguhago chukgureul haryeogo gongwone gasseoyo.
examples.en: He went to the park to play soccer with his friend.

title: ~하기로 [hagiro] (Decide to)
short_explanation: Used to express making a decision or plan to do something.
long_explanation: '~하기로 [hagiro]' is used when a decision or plan is made to carry out a certain action. It frequently appears in daily conversation to share decisions, future intentions, or arrangements. It can be translated as 'decide to ~' in English.

examples.kr: 우리는 내일 서울로 가기로 결정했어요. 거기서 친구들을 만나려고요.
examples.romaji: Urineun naeil Seoullo gagiro gyeoljeonghaesseoyo. Geogiseo chingudeureul mannaryeogoyo.
examples.en: We decided to go to Seoul tomorrow. We plan to meet friends there.

examples.kr: 나는 다음 달에 새로운 일을 시작하기로 결심했어요. 지금 하는 일이 너무 지루하거든요.
examples.romaji: Naneun daeum dare saeroun ireul sijakagiro gyeolsimhaesseoyo. Jigeum haneun iri neomu jiruhageodeunyo.
examples.en: I decided to start a new job next month because the one I have now is too boring.

examples.kr: 우리 가족은 다음 주말에 피크닉 가기로 했어요. 날씨가 좋을 예정이니까요.
examples.romaji: Uri gajogeun daeum jumare piknik gagiro haesseoyo. Nalssiga joeul yejeonginikkayo.
examples.en: Our family decided to go on a picnic next weekend, since the weather is supposed to be nice.

examples.kr: 나는 하루에 한 시간 독서하기로 했어요. 책을 읽으면 지식이 늘어나니까요.
examples.romaji: Naneun harue han sigan dokseohagiro haesseoyo. Chaekeul ilgeumyeon jisigi neuleonanikka yo.
examples.en: I decided to read for one hour every day because reading increases my knowledge.

title: ~하기는 [hagineun] (But, however)
short_explanation: Used to introduce a contrasting or limiting perspective: 'but', 'however'.
long_explanation: '~하기는 [hagineun]' is used in Korean to highlight a contrast or limitation. It conveys that while something may be true, there is a secondary point that limits or opposes the first statement. It often translates to 'but,' 'however,' or 'though' in English.

examples.kr: 날씨가 추웠기는 했지만, 우리는 아직도 즐거운 시간을 보냈어요.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga chuweotgineun haetjiman, urineun ajikdo jeulgeoun siganeul bonaesseoyo.
examples.en: The weather was cold, but we still had a good time.

examples.kr: 이 새별을 좋아하기는 해도, 너무 비싸서 사기 어려워요.
examples.romaji: I saebyeoreul johahagineun haedo, neomu bissaseo sagi eoryeowoyo.
examples.en: I do like this new star, but it's too expensive to buy.

examples.kr: 요리를 잘하긴 하나, 준비에 많은 시간과 노력이 필요해요.
examples.romaji: Yorireul jalhagin hana, junbie manheun sigangwa noryeogi piryohaeyo.
examples.en: I can cook well, but it requires a lot of time and effort to prepare.

examples.kr: 그는 성격이 좋기는 한데, 종종 늦게 오는 습관이 있어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun seonggyeogi johgineun hande, jongjong neujge oneun seubgwani isseoyo.
examples.en: He has a good personality, but he often has a habit of coming late.

title: ~하기보다 [hagiboda] (Rather than)
short_explanation: Used to compare two actions or states, expressing a preference: 'rather than', 'instead of'.
long_explanation: '~하기보다 [hagiboda]' is a Korean grammatical structure used when comparing or contrasting two actions, states, or situations. It introduces a preference for the second action over the first, translating to 'rather than' or 'instead of' in English. The verb before '~하기보다' is the less preferred, and what follows indicates the preferred action or situation.

examples.kr: 저는 차를 운전하기보다 버스를 타는 게 더 편해요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun chareul unjeonhagiboda beoseureul taneun ge deo pyeonhaeyo.
examples.en: It's more comfortable for me to take the bus rather than drive a car.

examples.kr: 음식을 사 먹기보다 직접 요리하는 게 더 건강해요.
examples.romaji: Eumsigeul sa meokgiboda jikjeop yorihaneun ge deo geonganghaeyo.
examples.en: Cooking your own food is healthier than buying it.

examples.kr: 집에서 일하기보다 사무실에서 작업하는 게 더 생산적이라고 생각해요.
examples.romaji: Jibeseo ilhagiboda samusileseo jageobhaneun ge deo saengsanjeogirago saenggakhaeyo.
examples.en: I think working in the office is more productive than working at home.

examples.kr: 돈을 벌기보다 친구들과 함께 시간을 보내는 게 더 중요하다고 생각해요.
examples.romaji: Doneul beolgiboda chingudeulgwa hamkke siganeul bonaeneun ge deo jungyohadago saenggakhaeyo.
examples.en: I believe spending time with friends is more important than making money.

title: ~하나 [hana] (Questioning oneself)
short_explanation: Used to show self-questioning or wondering; 'I wonder', 'Could it be'.
long_explanation: The ending '~하나 [hana]' in Korean expresses the speaker’s puzzlement or self-questioning about a situation. It often appears in more casual, reflective speech when the speaker wonders about something or asks themselves a rhetorical question. It's roughly similar to phrases like 'I wonder...' or 'Could it be...' in English.

examples.kr: 나는 왜 항상 혼자인지 모르겠는 하나.
examples.romaji: Naneun wae hangsang honjainji moreugenneun hana.
examples.en: I wonder why I'm always alone.

examples.kr: 왜 그가 저렇게 말했는지 이해가 안 가는 하나.
examples.romaji: Wae geuga jeoreoke malhaessneunji ihaega an ganeun hana.
examples.en: I'm puzzled as to why he said that.

examples.kr: 자주 연락하던 친구가 갑자기 연락이 안 오는 하나.
examples.romaji: Jaju yeonrakhadeon chinguga gapjagi yeonragi an oneun hana.
examples.en: I wonder why the friend who used to contact me often suddenly doesn't anymore.

examples.kr: 공부를 많이 했는데도 시험을 못 본다는 하나.
examples.romaji: Gongbureul mani haessneundedo siheomeul mot bondaneun hana.
examples.en: I wonder why, even though I studied a lot, I can't do well on the test.

title: ~하다가 [hadaga] (Doing and then)
short_explanation: Used to express the notion of 'doing something and then'.
long_explanation: '~하다가 [hadaga]' is a composite verb form in Korean meaning that while someone is in the middle of doing an action, another event occurs. It does not require the first action to finish before the second starts. Often, the second action interrupts or follows immediately after the first.

examples.kr: 청소를 하다가 우연히 오래된 사진을 발견했어요.
examples.romaji: Cheongsoreul hadaga uyeonhi oraedoen sajineul balgyeonhaesseoyo.
examples.en: While I was cleaning, I happened to find an old photo.

examples.kr: 저는 책을 읽다가 잠이 들었어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun chaekeul ilgdaga jami deureosseoyo.
examples.en: I was reading a book, and then I fell asleep.

examples.kr: 친구와 이야기를 하다가 시간을 잊었어요.
examples.romaji: Chinguwa iyagireul hadaga siganeul ilheosseoyo.
examples.en: I was talking with my friend and lost track of time.

examples.kr: 운전을 하다가 길을 잃었습니다.
examples.romaji: Unjeoneul hadaga gireul ilheosseumnida.
examples.en: I was driving and got lost.

title: ~하다가 말다 [hadaga malda] (Stop doing something)
short_explanation: Used to express that someone stops in the midst of doing something.
long_explanation: '~하다가 말다 [hadaga malda]' means that an action, which has begun, is interrupted or stopped before completion. It often implies the action may or may not resume later, highlighting a sudden change or interruption during the activity. The verb is typically in dictionary form before '하다가 말다.'

examples.kr: 공부하다가 말았어요, 왜냐하면 알람이 안 울려서 시간을 잊어버렸어요.
examples.romaji: Gongbuhadaga malasseoyo, waenyahamyeon allami an ullyeoseo siganeul ijeobeolyeosseoyo.
examples.en: I was studying and then stopped, because I forgot the time since the alarm didn't ring.

examples.kr: 친구가 집에 왔기 때문에 저는 밥 요리하다가 말았어요.
examples.romaji: Chinguga jibe watgi ttaemune jeoneun bab yori hadaga malasseoyo.
examples.en: I was cooking rice but then stopped because my friend came over.

examples.kr: 운동하다가 말았어요, 왜냐하면 비가 너무 많이 와서입니다.
examples.romaji: Undonghadaga malasseoyo, waenyahamyeon biga neomu mani waseoimnida.
examples.en: I was exercising and then stopped, because it was raining too much.

examples.kr: 책을 읽다가 말았어요, 왜냐하면 갑자기 잠이 왔거든요.
examples.romaji: Chaekeul ilgdaga malasseoyo, waenyahamyeon gapjagi jami watgeodeunyo.
examples.en: I was reading a book and then stopped because I suddenly felt sleepy.

title: ~하더라 [hadeora] (I observed, I remember)
short_explanation: Used to express a recollection or observation of a past event.
long_explanation: '~하더라 [hadeora]' indicates the speaker personally saw, felt, or experienced something in the past. It's more than simply stating a past fact (~했다); it emphasizes the speaker’s direct observation or impression of an event or situation.

examples.kr: 너의 여동생은 참 예쁘더라. 동네에서 가장 예쁜 소녀로 알려져 있었어.
examples.romaji: Neoui yeodongsaengeun cham yeppeudeora. Dongne-eseo gajang yeppeun sonyeoro allyeojyeo isseosseo.
examples.en: Your younger sister is really pretty. She was known as the most beautiful girl in the neighborhood.

examples.kr: 그는 항상 바빠 보였더라. 따라서 그를 만나기가 어려웠어.
examples.romaji: Geuneun hangsang bappa boyeossdeora. Ttaraseo geureul mannagiga eoryeowosseo.
examples.en: He always seemed busy, so it was difficult to find time to meet him.

examples.kr: 우리 아빠는 어릴 때 축구를 잘했더라. 그래서 아직도 축구 실력이 대단해.
examples.romaji: Uri appaneun eoril ttae chukgureul jalhaessdeora. Geuraeseo ajikdo chukgu sillyeogi daedanhae.
examples.en: My father was good at soccer when he was young, so he's still really skilled.

examples.kr: 작년에 우리가 해변에 갔던 때, 해가 질 무렵이 참 예뻤더라.
examples.romaji: Jagnyeone uriga haebyeone gatdeon ttae, haega jil muryeobi cham yeppeossdeora.
examples.en: Last year when we went to the beach, the time around sunset was really beautiful.

title: ~하려고 [haryeogo] (In order to)
short_explanation: Expresses purpose or intention: 'in order to', 'for the purpose of'.
long_explanation: '~하려고 [haryeogo]' is used to indicate an intention or purpose for doing something. It often translates to 'in order to' or 'for the purpose of' in English. This pattern appears before the main verb or clause that shows what the speaker aims to accomplish or why they’re performing an action.

examples.kr: 한국어를 더 잘 이해하려고 많은 책을 읽었습니다.
examples.romaji: Hangugeoreul deo jal ihaeharyeogo manheun chaegeul ilgeotseumnida.
examples.en: I read many books in order to understand Korean better.

examples.kr: 시험을 잘 보기 위해 열심히 공부하려고 해요.
examples.romaji: Siheomeul jal bogi wihae yeolsimhi gongbuharyeogo haeyo.
examples.en: I'm studying hard in order to do well on the test.

examples.kr: 건강을 유지하려고 운동하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Geongangeul yujiharyeogo undonghago isseoyo.
examples.en: I'm exercising to maintain my health.

examples.kr: 여행 경비를 모으려고 아르바이트를 했어요.
examples.romaji: Yeohaeng gyeongbireul moeuryeogo areubaiteureul haesseoyo.
examples.en: I did a part-time job in order to save money for my trip.

title: ~하여/해서 [hayeo/haeseo] (So, therefore)
short_explanation: A connective ending that expresses cause or reason.
long_explanation: '~하여/해서 [hayeo/haeseo]' is used in Korean to link two clauses, where the first clause is the cause or reason, and the second clause is the resulting action or statement. In colloquial speech, '해서' is more common. It corresponds to 'so' or 'therefore' in English.

examples.kr: 비가 와서 집에 늦게 왔어요.
examples.romaji: Biga waseo jibe neudge wasseoyo.
examples.en: Because it was raining, I got home late.

examples.kr: 컴퓨터가 망가져서 과제를 못 했어요.
examples.romaji: Keompyuteoga manggajyeoseo gwajereul mot haesseoyo.
examples.en: My computer broke, so I couldn't do my assignment.

examples.kr: 열심히 공부해서 시험을 잘 봤어요.
examples.romaji: Yeolsimhi gongbuhaeseo siheomeul jal bwasseoyo.
examples.en: I studied hard, so I did well on the test.

examples.kr: 빵을 너무 많이 먹어서 배가 아팠어요.
examples.romaji: Bbangeul neomu mani meogeoseo baega apasseoyo.
examples.en: I ate too much bread, so my stomach hurt.

title: ~한테/한테서 [hante/hanteseo] (To/From someone)
short_explanation: Indicates 'to' or 'from' a person or animate being.
long_explanation: '~한테 [hante]' and '~한테서 [hanteseo]' are postpositions used when the subject is sending something (physical or abstract) to someone, or receiving from someone. Typically used with people or animate beings: '한테' = 'to someone'; '한테서' = 'from someone'.

examples.kr: 제가 친구한테 선물을 주었어요.
examples.romaji: Jega chinguhante seonmureul jueosseoyo.
examples.en: I gave a present to my friend.

examples.kr: 제가 선생님한테서 한국어를 배웠어요.
examples.romaji: Jega seonsaengnim-hanteseo hangugeoreul baewosseoyo.
examples.en: I learned Korean from my teacher.

examples.kr: 그의 아버지한테서 돈을 빌렸어요.
examples.romaji: Geuui abeojihanteseo doneul billyeosseoyo.
examples.en: He borrowed money from his father.

examples.kr: 나한테 좋은 말만 해주세요.
examples.romaji: Nahante joheun malman haejuseyo.
examples.en: Please only say nice things to me.

title: ~할 거예요 [hal geoyeyo] (Going to do)
short_explanation: Expresses a future plan or intention: 'going to do'.
long_explanation: '~할 거예요 [hal geoyeyo]' is a common future tense form in Korean that conveys a plan, intention, or prediction, similar to 'be going to' in English. It shows that the action is expected to happen in the future.

examples.kr: 저는 이번 주말에 친구들과 함께 캠핑을 갈 거예요. 텐트와 캠핑용품을 준비해야 해요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun ibeon jumare chingudeulgwa hamkke kaempingeul gal geoyeyo. Tenteu wa kaempingyongpumeul junbihaeya haeyo.
examples.en: I'm going camping with my friends this weekend. I need to prepare tents and camping gear.

examples.kr: 내일은 날씨가 좋으니까 공원에서 산책할 거예요. 맑은 날씨를 만끽할 수 있을 거예요.
examples.romaji: Naeireun nalssiga joheunikka gongwoneseo sanchaekhal geoyeyo. Malgeun nalssireul mankkikhalsu isseul geoyeyo.
examples.en: Because the weather will be nice tomorrow, I'll go for a walk in the park. I'll be able to fully enjoy the clear weather.

examples.kr: 저는 저녁에 스파게티를 요리할 거예요. 스파게티 소스와 파스타를 사와야 해요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun jeonyeoge seupagetireul yorihal geoyeyo. Seupageti soseuwa paseutareul sawaya haeyo.
examples.en: I'm going to cook spaghetti this evening. I need to buy pasta and spaghetti sauce.

examples.kr: 아버지가 퇴근하면 함께 식당에서 저녁을 먹을 거예요. 아버지가 좋아하는 메뉴를 골라야 해요.
examples.romaji: Abeojiga toegeunhamyeon hamkke sikdangeseo jeonyeogeul meogeul geoyeyo. Abeojiga joahaneun menyureul gollaya haeyo.
examples.en: When my father gets off work, we'll eat dinner at a restaurant. I have to choose a menu my father likes.

title: ~할 만하다 [hal manhada] (Worth doing)
short_explanation: Indicates that an action is worth the effort, time, or cost: 'worth doing'.
long_explanation: '~할 만하다 [hal manhada]' means that an action is sufficiently valuable or beneficial to be worth the effort it requires. It can be used with many verbs to suggest that something is recommended or rewarding despite possible difficulty or expense.

examples.kr: 이 여행은 비싸지만 가볼 만해요. 그곳이 정말 아름다우니까요.
examples.romaji: I yeohaengeun bissajiman gabol manhaeyo. Geugosi jeongmal areumdawunikka yo.
examples.en: This trip is expensive, but it's worth going because it's really beautiful.

examples.kr: 이 영화는 길지만 볼 만합니다. 스토리가 굉장히 재미있어요.
examples.romaji: I yeonghwaneun giljiman bol manhamnida. Seutoriga gwaengjanghi jaemiisseoyo.
examples.en: This movie is long, but it's worth watching. The story is really interesting.

examples.kr: 이 책은 두껍지만 읽을 만해요. 내용이 무척 유익하거든요.
examples.romaji: I chaegeun dukkopjiman ilgeul manhaeyo. Naeyongi mucheok yuik-hageodeunyo.
examples.en: This book is thick, but it's worth reading. The content is very informative.

examples.kr: 이 식당은 멀지만 가볼 만해요. 음식이 정말 맛있어요.
examples.romaji: I sikdangeun meoljiman gabol manhaeyo. Eumsigi jeongmal masisseoyo.
examples.en: This restaurant is far, but it's worth visiting. The food is really delicious.

title: ~할수록 [hal surok] (The more...)
short_explanation: Used to describe a situation where one action or state increases or intensifies as another action or state does.
long_explanation: '~할수록 [hal surok]' is a compound grammar pattern used to express a situation where, as one thing progresses or changes, another thing happens correspondingly. Essentially, it means 'the more...'. It often involves a shared subject in both clauses, indicating proportional or dependent change in one factor alongside another.

examples.kr: 그녀를 알게 될수록 저는 그녀를 더 사랑하게 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoreul alge doelsurok jeoneun geunyeoreul deo saranghage doeeosseoyo.
examples.en: The more I got to know her, the more I fell in love with her.

examples.kr: 연습을 할수록 당신의 기술은 더 향상될 것입니다.
examples.romaji: Yeonseubeul halsurok dangsinui gisuleun deo hyangsangdoel geosimnida.
examples.en: The more you practice, the more your skills will improve.

examples.kr: 사람들이 많을수록 파티는 더 즐거워질 것입니다.
examples.romaji: Saramdeuri manheulsurok patineun deo jeulgeowojil geosimnida.
examples.en: The more people there are, the more fun the party will be.

examples.kr: 시간이 흘러갈수록 그의 그리움은 더 커져 갔어요.
examples.romaji: Sigani heulleogalsurok geuui geuriumeun deo keojyeo gasseoyo.
examples.en: As time passed, his longing grew even stronger.

title: ~할 줄 알다 [hal jul alda] (Know how to)
short_explanation: Used to express the knowledge or skill to do something.
