long_explanation: '~할 줄 알다 [hal jul alda]' is used to indicate that someone knows how to do a certain action or has the skill to do it. Literally, it means 'know the method of doing ~'.

examples.kr: 나는 요리할 줄 알아요, 그래서 친구들이 집에 놀러 올 때마다 맛있는 음식을 해 줄 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun yorihal jul arayo, geuraeseo chingudeuri jibe nolleo ol ttaemada masinneun eumsigeul hae jul su isseoyo.
examples.en: I know how to cook, so whenever my friends come over, I can make delicious food.

examples.kr: 제 친구는 한국어를 말할 줄 알아요, 그래서 한국 친구와 자유롭게 대화할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Je chinguneun hangugeoreul malhal jul arayo, geuraeseo hanguk chinguwa jayurobge daehwahal su isseoyo.
examples.en: My friend knows how to speak Korean, so he can talk freely with Korean friends.

examples.kr: 부모님은 운전을 하실 줄 아셔서 어디든지 가실 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Bumonimeun unjeoneul hasil jul asyeoseo eodideunji gasil su isseoyo.
examples.en: My parents know how to drive, so they can go anywhere.

examples.kr: 나는 피아노를 칠 줄 알아요, 그래서 노래방에 가면 항상 기분이 좋아요.
examples.romaji: Naneun pianoreul chil jul arayo, geuraeseo noraebange gamyeon hangsang gibuni joayo.
examples.en: I know how to play the piano, so I always feel good when I go to karaoke.

title: ~할지라도 [haljirado] (Even if)
short_explanation: Used to express a condition in the sense of 'even if'.
long_explanation: '~할지라도 [haljirado]' translates to 'even if' in English. It suggests that even under a hypothetical condition or possibility, the outcome or stance in the second clause remains unchanged.

examples.kr: 내일 비가 올지라도 나는 운동하러 갈 거예요.
examples.romaji: Naeil biga oljirado naneun undonghareo gal geoyeyo.
examples.en: Even if it rains tomorrow, I will go to exercise.

examples.kr: 부모님이 그를 싫어할지라도, 나는 계속 만나려고 해요.
examples.romaji: Bumonimi geureul sileohaljirado naneun gyesok mannaryeogo haeyo.
examples.en: Even if my parents dislike him, I intend to keep seeing him.

examples.kr: 시험이 어려울지라도, 열심히 공부했으니 자신 있어요.
examples.romaji: Siheomi eoryeouljirado yeolsimhi gongbuhaesseuni jasin isseoyo.
examples.en: Even if the exam is difficult, I'm confident because I've studied hard.

examples.kr: 네가 어떻게 생각할지라도 난 그 결정을 후회하지 않아.
examples.romaji: Nega eotteoke saenggakhaljirado nan geu gyeoljeongeul hugoehaji anha.
examples.en: Even if you think differently, I don't regret that decision.

title: ~할 텐데 [hal tende] (I thought/would have thought that...)
short_explanation: Expresses a presumption or expectation that differs from reality.
long_explanation: '~할 텐데 [hal tende]' conveys a speaker's assumption or prediction about a situation that turned out differently. It can be translated as 'I would have thought...' or 'I expected...' but the actual result was unexpected or contrary to the assumption.

examples.kr: 오늘 날씨가 좋을 텐데 비가 오네요. 예상을 빗나갔어요.
examples.romaji: Oneul nalssiga joheul tende biga oneyo. Yesangeul bitnagasseoyo.
examples.en: I thought the weather would be nice today, but it's raining. My prediction was off.

examples.kr: 그는 저녁에 연락할 텐데 아직 연락이 없어요. 뭔가 일이 생긴 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun jeonyeoge yeollakhal tende ajik yeollagi eopseoyo. Mwonga iri saenggin geot gatayo.
examples.en: I thought he would contact me in the evening, but he hasn't yet. Maybe something came up.

examples.kr: 그녀는 항상 밝을 텐데 오늘은 왠지 기분이 좋아 보이지 않아요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun hangsang balgeul tende oneureun waenji gibuni joa boiji anhayo.
examples.en: I would have thought she'd always be cheerful, but today she doesn't seem in a good mood.

examples.kr: 시험은 쉬울 텐데 정말 어렵게 나왔어요.
examples.romaji: Siheomeun swiul tende jeongmal eoryeopge nawasseoyo.
examples.en: I expected the exam to be easy, but it turned out to be really difficult.

title: ~해야지 [haeyaji] (Decide to)
short_explanation: Expresses a personal decision or resolution; similar to 'I should' or 'I will'.
long_explanation: '~해야지 [haeyaji]' indicates a personal decision or intent to do something. It can be translated as 'I should' or 'I will' and often sounds like talking to oneself or making a personal resolution. Sometimes it’s used in soft suggestions to others.

examples.kr: 오늘은 일찍 집에 가야지. 내일 일찍 일어나야 하거든.
examples.romaji: Oneureun iljjik jibe gayaji. Naeil iljjik ireonaya hageodeun.
examples.en: I should go home early today, because I have to wake up early tomorrow.

examples.kr: 건강을 위해 운동을 시작해야지.
examples.romaji: Geongangeul wihae undongeul sijakhaeyaji.
examples.en: I should start exercising for my health.

examples.kr: 나는 다양한 책을 읽어야지. 그래야 지식을 넓힐 수 있지.
examples.romaji: Naneun dayanghan chaekeul ilgeoyaji. Geuraeya jisigeul neolphil su itji.
examples.en: I should read a variety of books. That way, I can broaden my knowledge.

examples.kr: 천천히 먹어야지, 그래야 소화가 잘 될 거야.
examples.romaji: Cheoncheonhi meogeoyaji, geuraeya sohwaga jal doel geoya.
examples.en: I should eat slowly so it will digest well.

title: ~해도/해봐도 [haedo/haebwado] (Even if)
short_explanation: Indicates 'even if' or 'no matter how much' in sentences.
long_explanation: '~해도/해봐도 [haedo/haebwado]' is used to say that regardless of a certain action or attempt, the result or situation does not change. It conveys an idea of 'even if' or 'no matter how much one tries/does something.'
formation: Verb stem + 아/어/해도 or Verb stem + 아/어/해봐도

examples.kr: 여기서 우리가 얼마나 노력을 해봐도, 상황이 개선되지 않습니다.
examples.romaji: Yeogiseo uriga eolmana noryeokeul haebwado, sanghwang-i gaeseon doejiji anhseumnida.
examples.en: Even if we try hard here, the situation doesn't improve.

examples.kr: 그 가게의 음식이 맛있어도, 거기서 일하고 싶진 않아요.
examples.romaji: Geu gageui eumsigi masisseodo, geogiseo ilhago sipjin anhayo.
examples.en: Even if the food at that place is delicious, I don't want to work there.

examples.kr: 아무리 많은 돈을 벌어봐도 행복하지 않다면 의미가 없어요.
examples.romaji: Amuri manheun doneul beoreobwado haengbokhaji andamyeon uimiga eopseoyo.
examples.en: Even if you earn a lot of money, it's pointless if you're not happy.

examples.kr: 그녀가 얼마나 사랑해봐도, 그의 마음을 이해할 수 없대요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga eolmana saranghaebwado, geuui maeumeul ihaehal su eopdaeyo.
examples.en: No matter how much she loves him, she says she can’t understand his feelings.

title: ~해보다 [haeboda] (Try to)
short_explanation: Indicates attempting or trying an action for the first time, or suggesting someone try something.
long_explanation: '~해보다 [haeboda]' literally adds 'try' to a verb. It is used when someone attempts an action (often a new one) or suggests that another person try it. It conveys the sense of 'try doing (something)' in English.

examples.kr: 나는 새로운 한국 음식을 먹어보려고 노력했지만, 너무 낯설어서 어려웠어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun saeroun hanguk eumsigeul meogeoboryeogo noryeokhaetjiman, neomu natseoreoseo eoryeowosseoyo.
examples.en: I tried to eat new Korean food, but it was too unfamiliar and difficult.

examples.kr: 당신은 이 언어를 배워보는 것에 대해 어떻게 생각하세요?
examples.romaji: Dangsineun i eoneoreul baeweoboneun geose daehae eotteoke saenggakaseyo?
examples.en: What do you think about trying to learn this language?

examples.kr: 처음에는 읽기가 어려웠지만, 계속 해보니까 서서히 알게 됐어요.
examples.romaji: Cheoeumeneun ilgigiga eoryeowotjiman, gyesok haebonikka seoseohi alge dwaesseoyo.
examples.en: Reading was hard at first, but as I kept trying, I gradually came to understand.

examples.kr: 이번 주말에 새로운 취미를 찾아보는 건 어때요?
examples.romaji: Ibeon jumare saeroun chwimireul chajaboneun geon eottaeyo?
examples.en: How about trying to find a new hobby this weekend?

title: ~해주다 [haejuda] (Do for someone)
short_explanation: Indicates doing a favor or an action for someone else’s benefit.
long_explanation: '~해주다 [haejuda]' is used in Korean when you do something beneficial or helpful for another person. It often implies goodwill or kindness towards the recipient of the action, translating to 'do something for someone' in English.

examples.kr: 저는 어머니께 식사를 해주려고 요리를 배우고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun eomeonikke siksareul haejuryeogo yorireul baeugo isseoyo.
examples.en: I'm learning to cook in order to make meals for my mother.

examples.kr: 친구가 시험 공부를 힘들어해서 제가 정리를 해주었어요.
examples.romaji: Chinguga siheom gongbureul himdeureohaeseo jega jeongrireul haejueosseoyo.
examples.en: My friend was having a hard time studying for the exam, so I made a summary for her.

examples.kr: 아버지가 피곤하셔서 제가 운전을 해주었습니다.
examples.romaji: Abeojiga pigonhasyeoseo jega unjeoneul haejueotseumnida.
examples.en: My father was tired, so I drove for him.

examples.kr: 우리 팀원들이 바빠서 이번 보고서를 대신 작성해주었어요.
examples.romaji: Uri timwondeuri bappaseo ibeon bogoseoreul daesin jakseonghaejueosseoyo.
examples.en: Because our team members were busy, I wrote this report in their place.

title: ~했더니 [haetdeoni] (When, and then)
short_explanation: This grammar point is used to express 'when something happened and then something else happened as a result'.
long_explanation: '~했더니 [haetdeoni]' is a grammar point used in Korean to signify a cause-and-effect relationship where the first action directly leads to the second action. This construction denotes 'when I did [first action], and then [second action] happened'. It is often used in instances when the result is unexpected or surprising, emphasizing that the second action is a direct result of the first action.
formation: Verb in past tense + 더니 + Resulting action or state

examples.kr: 저는 이 케이크를 먹었더니 생각보다 훨씬 맛있어서 더 먹고 싶었어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun i keikeureul meogeosseodeoni saenggakboda hwolssin masisseoseo deo meokgo sippeosseoyo.
examples.en: When I ate this cake, it was much more delicious than I expected, and I wanted to eat more.

examples.kr: 나는 출근했더니 사무실에 아무도 없었어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun chulgeunhaessdeoni samusire amudo eopseosseoyo.
examples.en: When I came to work, there was nobody in the office.

examples.kr: 나는 이 책을 읽었더니 처음 생각했던 것보다 훨씬 재미있었어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun i chaegeul ilgeossdeoni cheoeum saenggakhaessdeon geotboda hwolssin jaemiisseosseoyo.
examples.en: When I read this book, it was much more interesting than I initially thought.

examples.kr: 나는 친구를 오랜만에 만났더니 정말 반가웠어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun chingureul oraenmane mannassdeoni jeongmal bangawosseoyo.
examples.en: When I met my friend after a long time, I was really glad.

title: ~했었다 [haesseotda] (Had done)
short_explanation: Used to describe an action that had been done in the past, before another action or situation.
long_explanation: '~했었다 [haesseotda]' is a verb ending used in Korean to express an action that had been completed before another event or action occurred. This form is similar to the English past perfect tense, often used to explain a past event or situation that happened prior to another past event. It can also be used to explain past regrets, experiences, and situations that were true in the past but not necessarily in the present.

examples.kr: 그날까지는 그녀를 보지 않았어요. 그러나 그 전에는 수없이 많은 편지들을 썼었어요.
examples.romaji: Geunalkkajineun geunyeoreul boji anhasseoyo. Geureona geu jeoneneun sueobsi maneun pyeonjideureul sseosseosseoyo.
examples.en: Until that day, I didn't see her. However, before that, I had written countless letters.

examples.kr: 처음 한국에 왔을 때, 저는 한글을 전혀 몰랐어요. 그렇지만 한국 아이들에게 알파벳을 가르치기 위해 한국어를 미리 배웠었어요.
examples.romaji: Cheoeum hanguke waseul ttae, jeoneun hangeureul jeonhyeo mollasseoyo. Geureochiman hanguk aideurege alphabeteul gareuchigi wihae hangugeoreul miri baeweosseosseoyo.
examples.en: When I first came to Korea, I didn't know any Hangul at all. Nevertheless, I had learned Korean beforehand to teach the alphabet to Korean children.

examples.kr: 그는 오늘 아침에 호텔로 왔었어요, 하지만 점심에는 그 학교에 있었어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun oneul achime hotello wasseosseoyo, hajiman jeomsimeneun geu hakgyoe isseosseoyo.
examples.en: He had come to the hotel this morning, but at lunchtime he was at that school.

examples.kr: 나는 그녀에게 단지 한 번만 인사했었어요. 그 후로는 그녀를 보지 못했어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun geunyeoege danji han beonman insahaesseosseoyo. Geu huroneun geunyeoreul boji moshaesseoyo.
examples.en: I had only greeted her once. After that, I couldn't see her.

title: ~했으면 [haesseumyeon] (If it were)
short_explanation: Used to express a hypothetical condition in the past; 'If it were', 'If it could be'.
long_explanation: '~했으면 [haesseumyeon]' is a Korean grammar structure used to express hypothetical situations or conditions in the past. It's often used to reflect wishes or to suppose different outcomes based on past events, and can be translated as 'If it had been...' or 'If I had done...' in English.

examples.kr: 그때 해외로 나갔으면 지금은 외롭지 않았을 거예요.
examples.romaji: Geuttae haeoero nagasseumyeon jigeumeun oereopji anasseul geoyeyo.
examples.en: If I had gone abroad at that time, I wouldn't feel so lonely now.

examples.kr: 답을 알았으면 시험에서 더 잘했을 거예요.
examples.romaji: Dabeul arasseumyeon siheomeseo deo jalhaesseul geoyeyo.
examples.en: If I had known the answer, I would have done better on the test.

examples.kr: 당신이 저를 그때 도와줬으면, 저는 실패하지 않았을 거예요.
examples.romaji: Dangsini jeoreul geuttae dowajwosseumyeon, jeoneun silpaehaji anasseul geoyeyo.
examples.en: If you had helped me then, I would not have failed.

examples.kr: 그 일을 빨리 처리했으면, 지금 이 문제를 겪지 않았을 거예요.
examples.romaji: Geu ireul ppalli cheorihasseumyeon, jigeum i munjereul gyeokji anasseul geoyeyo.
examples.en: If I had handled that work quickly, I wouldn't be facing this problem now.

title: ~했을 때 [haesseul ttae] (When someone did)
short_explanation: Used to express the time when a particular action or event took place.
long_explanation: '~했을 때 [haesseul ttae]' is a verb ending used in Korean to indicate the time when a specific action or event happened in the past. It is typically translated as 'when someone did' in English. It connects two clauses: the first describes the action/event in the past, the second describes the result or consequence.
formation: Verb in past tense + 았을 때/었을 때

examples.kr: 나는 어렸을 때 가족과 많이 여행 갔어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun eoryeosseul ttae gajokgwa mani yeohaeng gasseoyo.
examples.en: When I was young, I used to travel a lot with my family.

examples.kr: 처음 한국어를 배웠을 때 말하기가 정말 어려웠어요.
examples.romaji: Cheoeum hangugeoreul baewosseul ttae malhagiga jeongmal eoryeowosseoyo.
examples.en: When I first learned Korean, speaking was really difficult.

examples.kr: 그가 도서관에 갔을 때 저는 기다려야 했어요.
examples.romaji: Geuga doseogwane gasseul ttae jeoneun gidaryeoya haesseoyo.
examples.en: When he went to the library, I had to wait.

examples.kr: 당신이 울었을 때 나도 슬퍼진다는 걸 알게 됐어요.
examples.romaji: Dangshini ureosseul ttae nado seulpeojindaneun geol alge dwaesseoyo.
examples.en: When you cried, I realized that I also become sad.

title: ~했을 텐데 [haesseul tende] (I think I did)
short_explanation: Used to express a strong assumption or belief about a past action or state.
long_explanation: '~했을 텐데' is a grammatical expression used in Korean to indicate a strong assumption or belief regarding a past action or state. The speaker believes that the action mentioned likely occurred (or was true), but they do not have direct or definite confirmation. It can also convey a sense of regret or speculation about what probably happened.

examples.kr: 나는 그 양식을 이미 제출했을 텐데 왜 다시 요구하는지 모르겠어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun geu yangsigeul imi jechulhaesseul tende wae dasi yoguhaneunji moreugesseoyo.
examples.en: I think I've already submitted that form, but I don't know why they're asking for it again.

examples.kr: 그는 그 소식을 들었을 텐데 아직 반응이 없네요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun geu sosigeul deureosseul tende ajik baneungi eopneyo.
examples.en: He must have heard the news, but he hasn't responded yet.

examples.kr: 우리는 그 날 회의에 참석했을 텐데 이름이 명단에 없네요.
examples.romaji: Urineun geu nal hoeuie chamseokhaesseul tende ireumi myeongdane eopneyo.
examples.en: We should have attended the meeting that day, but our names aren't on the list.

examples.kr: 그녀는 이 연락을 받았을 텐데 아직 답장이 오지 않았어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun i yeonrageul badasseul tende ajik dapjangi oji anasseoyo.
examples.en: She should have received this message, but she hasn't replied yet.

title: ~했지만 [haetjiman] (But, however)
short_explanation: Used to express a contrast or contradiction; 'but', 'however'.
long_explanation: '~했지만 [haetjiman]' is a conjunctive form used in Korean to indicate a contrast or contradiction between two clauses. It is similar to the English conjunctions 'but' or 'however', combining sentences that show a difference or unexpected turn.

examples.kr: 여행을 많이 가고 싶었지만, 시간이 없어서 못 갔어요.
examples.romaji: Yeohaengeul mani gago sipeotjiman, sigani eopseoseo mot gasseoyo.
examples.en: I wanted to travel a lot, but I couldn't because I didn't have time.

examples.kr: 저는 공부를 열심히 했지만, 시험에서 높은 점수를 받지 못했어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun gongbureul yeolsimhi haetjiman, siheomeseo nopeun jeomsureul batji moshaesseoyo.
examples.en: Although I studied hard, I did not get high scores on the exam.

examples.kr: 그는 재미있는 일을 많이 하고 싶었지만, 매일 밤 일해야 했어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun jaemiinneun ireul mani hago sipeotjiman, maeil bam ilhaeya haesseoyo.
examples.en: He wanted to do a lot of fun things, but he had to work every night.

examples.kr: 친구들과 함께 놀고 싶었지만, 과제 때문에 나갈 수 없었어요.
examples.romaji: Chingudeulgwa hamkke nolgo sipeotjiman, gwaje ttaemune nagal su eopseosseoyo.
examples.en: I wanted to hang out with my friends, but I couldn't go out due to assignments.

title: ~아/어/여서 [a/eo/yeoseo] (Because, so)
short_explanation: Used to indicate the reason or cause for something; can be translated as 'because' or 'so'.
long_explanation: The '~아/어/여서' ending is used in Korean to denote a cause-and-effect relationship between two clauses. The clause that contains '~아/어/여서' indicates the reason or cause, and the main clause describes the result. Which form (아/어/여) you use depends on the verb stem’s final vowel or '하다' (which becomes '해서').

examples.kr: 저는 배가 고파서 밥을 많이 먹었어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun baega gopaseo babeul manhi meogeosseoyo.
examples.en: I ate a lot because I was hungry.

examples.kr: 그는 성격이 좋아서 친구가 많아요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun seonggyeogi joaseo chinguga manhayo.
examples.en: He has a lot of friends because he has a good personality.

examples.kr: 나는 기차가 늦어서 회사에 늦었어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun gichaga neujeoseo hoesae neujeosseoyo.
examples.en: I was late to the office because the train was late.

examples.kr: 이 방이 너무 시끄러워서 공부를 할 수 없어요.
examples.romaji: I bangi neomu sikkeureowoseo gongbureul hal su eopseoyo.
examples.en: I can't study because this room is too noisy.

title: ~아/어/여야 [a/eo/yeoya] (Have to)
short_explanation: Used to express necessity or obligation; 'have to', 'must'.
long_explanation: '~아/어/여야' is a Korean grammar pattern used to indicate that a certain action must be done or a condition must be met, similar to 'have to' or 'must' in English. The verb stem is followed by 아/어/여야 (and often combined with 하다 or 되다) to convey obligation.

examples.kr: 기말고사를 위해 어려운 문제들을 많이 풀어야 합니다.
examples.romaji: Gimalgosareul wihae eoryeoun munjedeureul mani pureoya habnida.
examples.en: I have to solve many difficult problems for the final exam.

examples.kr: 오늘은 일찍 자야 내일 피곤을 피할 수 있을 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Oneureun iljjik jaya naeil pigoneul pihal su isseul geot gatayo.
examples.en: I have to go to bed early today to avoid being tired tomorrow.

examples.kr: 나는 이번 달을 위해 더 많이 돈을 벌어야 해요.
examples.romaji: Naneun ibeon dareul wihae deo mani doneul beoreoya haeyo.
examples.en: I have to earn more money for this month.

examples.kr: 프로젝트 제출 전에 팀원들과 미팅을 하여야 합니다.
examples.romaji: Peurojekteu jechul jeone timweondeulgwa mitingeul hayeoya habnida.
examples.en: We have to have a meeting with the team members before submitting the project.

title: ~후에 [hue] (After)
short_explanation: Used to indicate that an action or event happens after another action or event.
long_explanation: '~후에 [hue]' is a time-related grammar point in Korean that means 'after'. It connects two different events or actions, emphasizing the chronological order: the second event happens after the first.

examples.kr: 저는 학교를 졸업한 후에 바로 일을 찾으러 갔어요. 다른 일이 있어서 쉴 시간이 없었어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hakgyoreul joreophan hue baro ireul chajeureo gasseoyo. Dareun iri isseoseo swil sigani eopseosseoyo.
examples.en: After I graduated from school, I immediately went to find a job. I had no time to rest because there were other things to do.

examples.kr: 저는 매일 일어난 후에 운동을 하고 다시 집에 돌아와서 준비를 해요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun maeil ileonan hue undongeul hago dasi jibe dorawaseo junbireul haeyo.
examples.en: After I wake up every day, I exercise and then come back home to get ready.

examples.kr: 밥을 먹은 후에 휴식 시간이 있어서 친구들과 대화를 나눠요.
examples.romaji: Babeul meogeun hue hyusik sigani isseoseo chingudeulgwa daehwareul nanwoyo.
examples.en: After eating, I have some break time and talk with my friends.

examples.kr: 공부를 한 후에 시험을 볼 것이지만, 시간이 많이 없어요.
examples.romaji: Gongbureul han hue siheomeul bol geosijiman, sigani mani eopseoyo.
examples.en: I'm going to take the test after studying, but I don't have much time.

title: ~(으)나 [(eu)na] (But, however)
short_explanation: Used to express contradiction or opposition; 'but', 'however'.
long_explanation: '~(으)나 [(eu)na]' is a conjunction used in Korean to indicate a contrast or contradiction between two clauses or sentences. It delivers a meaning similar to 'but' or 'however' in English, and is often used when presenting a surprising or opposing fact.

examples.kr: 오늘은 사실 기분이 좋으나, 날씨가 비가 올 것 같아서 조금 힘이 들어요.
examples.romaji: Oneureun sasil gibuni joeuna, nalssiga biga ol geot gataseo jogeum himi deureoyo.
examples.en: I actually feel good today, but it looks like it's going to rain, which is a bit tiring.

examples.kr: 집에 가고 싶으나, 공부를 더 해야 해서 학교에 머물러야 해요.
examples.romaji: Jibe gago sipuna, gongbureul deo haeya haeseo hakgyoe meomulleoya haeyo.
examples.en: I want to go home, but I need to study more, so I have to stay at school.

examples.kr: 나는 물론 친구들도 이 영화를 볼 계획이었으나, 표가 다 매진되어서 볼 수 없었어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun mullon chingudeuldo i yeonghwareul bol gyehoegieosseuna, pyoga da maejindoeeoseo bol su eopseosseoyo.
examples.en: Not only I but also my friends planned to watch this movie, but the tickets were all sold out so we couldn't see it.

examples.kr: 숙제가 많으나, 워낙 지독하게 어려워서 정말로 어떻게 할지 모르겠어요.
examples.romaji: Sukjega manhna, wonak jidokhage eoryeowoseo jeongmallo eotteohge halji moreugesseoyo.
examples.en: I have a lot of homework, but it's so terribly difficult that I really don't know what to do.

title: ~(으)ㄹ까요? [(eu)lkka yo?] (Shall we?)
short_explanation: Used to make a suggestion or proposal to do something together.
long_explanation: '~(으)ㄹ까요?' is a Korean sentence ending used when the speaker proposes doing something together. With verbs ending in a vowel, 'ㄹ까요?' is added, while those ending in a consonant take '을까요?'. It corresponds to 'Shall we...?' or 'Should we...?' in English.

examples.kr: 우리 사진 찍을까요? 날씨가 좋아서 멋진 사진이 나올 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Uri sajin jjigeulkka yo? Nalssiga joaseo meotjin sajini naol geot gatayo.
examples.en: Shall we take a photo? The weather is nice, so I think we'll get a great picture.

examples.kr: 점심시간에 함께 운동할까요? 몸을 움직이는 것이 건강에 좋잖아요.
examples.romaji: Jeomsimsigane hamkke undonghalkka yo? Momeul umjigineun geosi geongange johjanayo.
examples.en: Shall we exercise together at lunchtime? It's good for our health to get moving.

examples.kr: 이번 주말에 영화를 볼까요? 재미있는 영화가 많이 개봉했어요.
examples.romaji: Ibeon jumale yeonghwareul bolkka yo? Jaemiinneun yeonghwaga mani gaebonghaesseoyo.
examples.en: Shall we watch a movie this weekend? A lot of fun movies have been released.

examples.kr: 같이 커피를 마실까요? 커피를 마시면서 이야기 나누면 좋을 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Gachi keopireul masilkka yo? Keopireul masimyeonseo iyagi nanumyeon joheul geot gatayo.
examples.en: Shall we have a coffee together? I think it would be nice to talk while we drink.

title: ~(으)ㄹ래요 [(eu)llae yo] (I will)
short_explanation: This grammar point is used when the speaker is suggesting doing something or explaining his/her intention.
long_explanation: '~(으)ㄹ래요 [(eu)llae yo]' is a Korean grammar structure used to express the speaker's intention or decision to perform an action. It can also indicate a suggestion, inviting others to join or agree. It is typically used in informal or polite-casual situations among friends, family, and people who are about the same age or younger.

examples.kr: 저녁에 같이 영화를 볼래요? 제가 좋은 영화를 찾아봤어요.
examples.romaji: Jeonyeoge gachi yeonghwareul bollae yo? Jega joheun yeonghwareul chajabwasseoyo.
examples.en: Do you want to watch a movie together this evening? I found a good one.

examples.kr: 날씨가 좋으니까 밖에서 점심을 먹을래요. 신선한 공기를 즐기면서 식사할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga joheunikka bakk-eseo jeomsimeul meogeullae yo. Sinseonhan gonggireul jeulgimyeonseo siksahal su isseoyo.
examples.en: Since the weather is nice, I want to eat lunch outside. We can enjoy the fresh air while dining.

examples.kr: 오늘 저녁에 저와 체스를 둘래요? 오랫동안 연습해 왔어요.
examples.romaji: Oneul jeonyeoge jeowa cheseureul dullae yo? Oraetdongan yeonseuphae wasseoyo.
examples.en: Do you want to play chess with me this evening? I’ve been practicing for a long time.

examples.kr: 당신의 분실물을 찾을래요. 택시 기사님께 연락해 볼게요.
examples.romaji: Dangsinui bunsilmureul chajeullae yo. Taeksi gisanimkke yeollakhae bolgeyo.
examples.en: I will look for your lost item. I’ll try contacting the taxi driver.

title: ~(으)면서 [(eu)myeonseo] (While)
short_explanation: Used to express 'while' or 'at the same time' in Korean.
long_explanation: '~(으)면서 [(eu)myeonseo]' is used in Korean to denote simultaneous actions or states. It is similar to 'while' in English, indicating that two or more actions are happening at the same time. It can also be used to express contradictions between two clauses, akin to 'but' or 'however', especially when the two clauses seem unexpected together.

examples.kr: 저는 학교에 다니면서 풀타임으로 일하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hakgyoe danimyeonseo pultaimeuro ilhago isseoyo.
examples.en: I'm working full time while attending school.

examples.kr: 승민은 음악을 들으면서 공부를 하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Seungmin-eun eumageul deureumyeonseo gongbureul hago isseoyo.
examples.en: Seungmin is studying while listening to music.

examples.kr: 그는 눈물을 흘리면서 웃었어요. 기쁨이 넘쳐서 그랬어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun nunmureul heullimyeonseo useosseoyo. Gippeumi neomchyeoseo geuraesseoyo.
examples.en: He laughed while shedding tears, because his joy was overflowing.

examples.kr: 할머니는 요리도 하면서 사랑방에서 얘기를 해주시는데, 나는 그게 능력이라고 생각해요.
examples.romaji: Halmeonineun yorido hamyeonseo sarangbang-eseo yaegireul haejusineunde, naneun geuge neungnyeokirago saenggakhaeyo.
examples.en: My grandma cooks and also tells stories at the same time in the living room — I think that’s a real skill.

title: ~(으)로 [(eu)ro] (Towards, by means of)
short_explanation: This particle is used to express direction, means or method, or the purpose of an action.
long_explanation: '~(으)로 [(eu)ro]' is a particle in Korean that can express: (1) the direction towards which an action is made, (2) the means or method by which an action is carried out, or (3) the intended result or purpose of an action. Depending on context, it can correspond to English prepositions like 'to', 'by', 'with', 'as', or 'for'.
formation: If the preceding noun ends with a vowel, use '로'. If it ends with a consonant, use '으로'.

examples.kr: 저는 매일 아침 지하철로 회사에 가요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun maeil achim jihacheollo hoesae gayo.
examples.en: I go to the office by subway every morning.

examples.kr: 나는 이 문제를 해결하기 위해 새로운 방법으로 시도했어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun i munjereul haegyeolhagi wihae saeroun bangbeobeuro sidohaesseoyo.
examples.en: I tried a new method to solve this problem.

examples.kr: 저는 친구를 공항으로 배웅했어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun chingureul gonghangeuro baewunghaesseoyo.
examples.en: I saw my friend off at the airport.

examples.kr: 여행 계획을 세우는 것은 종이와 펜으로 했어요.
examples.romaji: Yeohaeng gyehwaekeul seuneun geoseun jongiwa pen-euro haesseoyo.
examples.en: I planned the trip with paper and pen.

title: ~(으)로서 [(eu)roseo] (As)
short_explanation: Used to mean 'as' or 'in the capacity of'.
long_explanation: The Korean grammar point '~(으)로서 [(eu)roseo]' is used to express the concept of doing or existing in the capacity or status of something or someone. This is akin to the English preposition 'as'. If the noun ends with a consonant, use 으로서; if the noun ends with a vowel, use 로서.
formation: Consonant-ending noun + 으로서 / Vowel-ending noun + 로서

examples.kr: 기자로서의 역할을 최선을 다해 수행하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Gijaroseo-ui yeokhareul choeseoneul dahae suhaenghago isseoyo.
examples.en: I’m doing my best to fulfill my role as a journalist.

examples.kr: 나는 한 학생으로서 내 의무를 다해야 해요.
examples.romaji: Naneun han haksaengeuroseo nae uimureul dahaya haeyo.
examples.en: I, as a student, have to fulfill my duties.

examples.kr: 마지막으로, 국민으로서 아주 중요한 일을 하여야 합니다.
examples.romaji: Majimag-euro, gungmin-euroseo aju jungyohan ireul hayeoya hamnida.
examples.en: Lastly, as a citizen, I have a very important task to do.

examples.kr: 어머니로서 그녀는 항상 가족을 위해 최선을 다합니다.
examples.romaji: Eomeoniroseo geunyeoneun hangsang gajokeul wihae choeseoneul dahabnida.
examples.en: As a mother, she always does her best for her family.

title: ~(으)로써 [(eu)rosseo] (By, as)
short_explanation: Used to express the means or method of something; similar to 'by', 'as', or 'via' in English.
long_explanation: '~(으)로써 [(eu)rosseo]' is used in Korean to indicate the method or means by which something is accomplished, or the capacity in which someone is acting. It emphasizes 'by means of', 'with', 'as', or 'via'. In everyday speech, '~(으)로써' is somewhat formal/literary, while '(으)로' often suffices. But '(으)로써' more explicitly stresses the means or instrument.

examples.kr: 저는 이 성과를 이루기 위해 노력으로써 성공했습니다.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun i seonggwaleul irugi wihae noryeogeurosseo seonggonghaesseumnida.
examples.en: I achieved this result by means of my effort.

examples.kr: 그는 시간 관리로써 스스로를 통제하는 방법을 배웠습니다.
examples.romaji: Geuneun sigan gwanlilrosseo seuseuroreul tongjehaneun bangbeobeul baewasseumnida.
examples.en: He learned how to control himself through time management.

examples.kr: 이 숙제는 그녀의 가르침으로써 완성했습니다.
examples.romaji: I sukjeneun geunyeoui gareuchimeurosseo wanseonghaesseumnida.
examples.en: I completed this homework by means of her teachings.

examples.kr: 감독으로써 그는 영화를 완성했습니다.
examples.romaji: Gamdogeurosseo geuneun yeonghwareul wanseonghaesseumnida.
examples.en: As a director, he completed the film.

title: ~(으)려고 하다 [(eu)ryeogo hada] (To try to)
short_explanation: This structure is used to express 'trying to do' something or 'intending to do' something.
long_explanation: '~(으)려고 하다 [(eu)ryeogo hada]' is a useful grammar pattern in Korean that indicates an intention or a plan to perform an action in the future. It corresponds to English expressions like 'I’m going to…' or 'I intend to…'. It can also show that someone is actively making an effort to achieve a goal.

examples.kr: 저는 한국어를 더 잘하려고 매일 연습을 많이 해요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hangugeoreul deo jalaryeogo maeil yeonseubeul manhi haeyo.
examples.en: I practice every day because I’m trying to improve my Korean.

examples.kr: 우리 어머니는 맛있는 저녁 식사를 준비하려고 요리 공부를 하세요.
examples.romaji: Uri eomeonineun masinneun jeonyeok siksareul junbiharyeogo yori gongbureul haseyo.
examples.en: My mother studies cooking because she’s trying to prepare a delicious dinner.

examples.kr: 동생은 더 큰 키를 위해 매일 운동을 하려고 해요.
examples.romaji: Dongsaeng-eun deo keun kireul wihae maeil undongeul haryeogo haeyo.
examples.en: My younger sibling exercises every day to try to grow taller.

examples.kr: 친구가 추천해 준 새로운 앱을 사용하려고 전화를 업데이트했어요.
examples.romaji: Chinguga chucheonhae jun saeroun aebeul sayongharyeogo jeonhwareul eopdeiteuhaesseoyo.
examples.en: I updated my phone to try the new app my friend recommended.

title: ~(으)리라 [(eu)rira] (Probably)
short_explanation: This grammar form is used to express a supposition or assumption by the speaker, similar to 'probably' in English.
long_explanation: '~(으)리라 [(eu)rira]' is a somewhat formal or literary form in Korean used when the speaker is making a supposition or assumption about something, much like 'probably' in English. If the verb stem ends in a consonant, add '으리라'; if it ends in a vowel, simply use '리라.' It can appear in both daily speech and writing, although it has a slightly more elevated nuance.

examples.kr: 그가 아마 내일 출근하리라 생각해요.
examples.romaji: Geuga ama naeil chulgeunharira saenggakhaeyo.
examples.en: I suppose he will probably come to work tomorrow.

examples.kr: 기말고사 성적이 좋으리라 확신하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Gimalgosa seongjeogi joeurira hwaksinhago isseoyo.
examples.en: I’m convinced that my final exam scores will probably be good.

examples.kr: 비가 오리라 생각해서 우산을 가져왔어요.
examples.romaji: Biga orira saenggakhaeseo usaneul gajyeowasseoyo.
examples.en: I brought an umbrella thinking it would probably rain.

examples.kr: 저는 회사에서 빠르게 승진하리라 예상했어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hoesaeseo ppareuge seungjinharira yesanghaesseoyo.
examples.en: I expected that I would probably be promoted quickly at the company.

title: ~(으)실 거예요 [(eu)sil geoyeyo] (You will probably)
short_explanation: This grammar point is used to express an educated guess or assumption about a future action, typically regarding a third person or in polite speech.
long_explanation: '~(으)실 거예요 [(eu)sil geoyeyo]' is a future tense form that expresses a polite assumption about someone's future action or state. The speaker is making an educated guess based on available information. It can also convey someone’s future plan in an honorific/polite way.

examples.kr: 어머니는 내일 아침 일찍 나가실 거예요. 미리 아침밥을 준비해 두세요.
examples.romaji: Eomeonineun naeil achim iljjik nagasil geoyeyo. Miri achimbabeul junbihae duseyo.
examples.en: Mother will probably leave early tomorrow morning, so prepare breakfast in advance.

examples.kr: 선생님은 이 문제에 대해 많이 알고 계실 거예요.
examples.romaji: Seonsaengnimeun i munje-e daehae mani algo gyesil geoyeyo.
examples.en: The teacher will probably know a lot about this problem.

examples.kr: 우리 부모님은 아마 다음 주에 회사에 가실 거라고 생각하실 거예요.
examples.romaji: Uri bumonimeun ama daeum jue hoesae gasil georago saenggakhasil geoyeyo.
examples.en: Our parents will probably think that they’ll go to the office next week.

examples.kr: 대통령님은 내년에도 여기를 방문하실 거예요.
examples.romaji: Daetongryeongnimeun naenyeonedo yeogireul bangmunhasil geoyeyo.
examples.en: The president will probably visit here again next year.

title: ~(으)면 좋겠다 [(eu)myeon jokgetda] (It would be good if)
short_explanation: Used to express a hope or wish for something to occur in the future.
long_explanation: '~(으)면 좋겠다 [(eu)myeon jokgetda]' is a structure used in Korean to articulate a hope, wish, or desire for a future event or situation. It is similar to saying 'It would be nice if...' or 'I wish...' in English.

examples.kr: 내일 날씨가 좋으면 좋겠어요. 외출 계획이 있어서 맑은 하늘이었으면 해요.
examples.romaji: Naeil nalssiga joeumyeon jokgesseoyo. Oechul gyehoegi isseoseo malgeun haneurieosseumyeon haeyo.
examples.en: It would be good if the weather is nice tomorrow. I have plans to go out, so I’d like a clear sky.

examples.kr: 시험에서 잘 보면 좋겠다. 많은 노력을 들였거든요.
examples.romaji: Siheomeseo jal bomyeon jokgetda. Maneun noryeogeul deuryeotgeodeunyo.
examples.en: I hope I do well on the exam. I put in a lot of effort.

examples.kr: 치킨을 먹으면 좋겠다. 치킨이 너무 좋아서요.
examples.romaji: Chikineul meogeumyeon jokgetda. Chikini neomu joaseoyo.
examples.en: I wish I could eat chicken, because I really love it.

examples.kr: 여행을 갈 수 있으면 좋겠다. 집에 갇혀 있어서 너무 지루해.
examples.romaji: Yeohaengeul gal su isseumyeon jokgetda. Jibe gathyeo isseoseo neomu jiruhae.
examples.en: It would be nice if I could go on a trip. I’m so bored being stuck at home.

title: ~(으)면서도 [(eu)myeonseodo] (While, although)
short_explanation: Used to express 'while' or 'although', indicating a situation or action that happens concurrently with another, or contrary to expectation.
long_explanation: The grammar point '~(으)면서도' is used in Korean to indicate that an event or situation is happening while another is also taking place, or when something is contrary to expectation. It can be translated as 'while' or 'although'. This form can be used with both action verbs and descriptive verbs. You can express the continuation of two situations at the same time, or describe a contrasting situation that defies expectation.

examples.kr: 그는 화가 나면서도 미소를 지었다.
examples.romaji: Geuneun hwaga namyeonseodo misoreul jieossda.
examples.en: Although he was angry, he smiled.

examples.kr: 그녀는 아프면서도 학교에 갔다.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun apeumyeonseodo hakgyoe gassda.
examples.en: Although she was sick, she went to school.

examples.kr: 비가 오면서도 방송은 계속해서 진행 중이었어요.
examples.romaji: Biga omyeonseodo bangsong-eun gyesokhaeseo jinhaeng jungieosseoyo.
examples.en: Although it was raining, the broadcast continued.

examples.kr: 이 어린아이는 영화를 보면서도 언제나 놀기 위한 계획을 세우고 있었다.
examples.romaji: I eoriniaineun yeonghwareul bomyeonseodo eonjena nolgi wihan gyehoeg-eul seugo isseossda.
examples.en: While watching the movie, this little child was always planning to play.

title: ~(으)니까 [(eu)nikka] (Because, Since)
short_explanation: Used to express cause and effect, or to provide a reason or explanation.
long_explanation: '~(으)니까' is a conjunction used in Korean to express the relationship of cause and effect between two clauses, similar to 'because' or 'since' in English. It attaches to the verb (or adjective) stem, stating the reason why something is or will be in a certain state, or explaining the cause of an action or situation.

examples.kr: 점심 먹었으니까 지금은 배가 고프지 않아요.
examples.romaji: Jeomsim meogeosseunikka jigeumeun baega gopeuji anhayo.
examples.en: Because I had lunch, I'm not hungry now.

examples.kr: 은행에 갔으니까 돈을 인출할 수 있었어요.
examples.romaji: Eunhaeng-e gasseunikka doneul inchulhal su isseosseoyo.
examples.en: Since I went to the bank, I was able to withdraw money.

examples.kr: 조용히 공부하고 있으니까 방해하지 마세요.
examples.romaji: Joyonghi gongbuhago isseunikka banghaehaji maseyo.
examples.en: I am studying quietly, so do not disturb me.

examples.kr: 비가 오고 있으니까 우산을 가져가세요.
examples.romaji: Biga ogo isseunikka usaneul gajyeogaseyo.
examples.en: Because it's raining, take an umbrella.

title: ~(으)다 보니 [(eu)da boni] (Seeing that, as)
short_explanation: Used to show the reason or cause of a certain result or situation based on a continuous action or state.
long_explanation: '~(으)다 보니' is a grammatical construct in Korean that expresses a result or realization that naturally occurred through ongoing action or state. It's similar to the English expressions 'seeing that' or 'as a result of (continuing to do something)'. It shows that one thing led naturally or inevitably to another.

examples.kr: 빨리 왔다 보니 시작하기 전에 잠시 쉴 수 있겠어요.
examples.romaji: Ppalli watda boni sijak-hagi jeone jamsi swil su igesseoyo.
examples.en: Seeing that I've come early, I can rest a bit before we start.

examples.kr: 한 달 동안 매일 운동하다 보니 체중이 좀 빠졌어요.
examples.romaji: Han dal dongan maeil undonghada boni chejungi jom ppajyeosseoyo.
examples.en: Because I worked out every day for a month, I lost some weight.

examples.kr: 꾸준히 공부하다 보니 점점 한국어 실력이 늘었어요.
examples.romaji: Kkujunhi gongbuhada boni jeomjeom hangugeo sillyeogi neuleosseoyo.
examples.en: By studying steadily, I found my Korean skills gradually improving.

examples.kr: 매일 아침 일찍 일어나다 보니 점심을 먹으면 바로 피곤해져요.
examples.romaji: Maeil achim iljjik ireonada boni jeomsimeul meogeumyeon baro pigonhaejyeoyo.
examples.en: Since I wake up early every morning, I get tired right after eating lunch.

title: ~(으)다가 [(eu)daga] (And then, but)
short_explanation: Expresses a sequence of actions or represents a contrast in situations.
long_explanation: '~(으)다가' is a common Korean grammar point that can mean 'and then' (one action followed by another) or show a shift from one action/situation to a different or contrasting one. It may translate to 'while doing something, then...' or 'but suddenly...' in English, depending on context.
formation: Verb stem + 다가 / Verb stem + 으다가 (If the verb stem ends in a consonant)

examples.kr: 나는 책을 읽다가 잠이 들어 버려서 마지막 부분을 읽지 못했어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun chaegeul ilgdaga jami deureo beoryeoseo majimak bubuneul ilgji mothaesseoyo.
examples.en: I was reading a book and then fell asleep, so I couldn't read the last part.

examples.kr: 우리는 영화를 보다가 갑자기 전기가 나가서 끝부분을 볼 수 없었어요.
examples.romaji: Urineun yeonghwareul bodaga gapjagi jeongiga nagaseo kkeutbubuneul bol su eopseosseoyo.
examples.en: We were watching a movie, but suddenly the power went out, so we couldn't see the end.

examples.kr: 그는 말하다가 갑자기 웃음을 터뜨려서 모두를 놀라게 했어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun malhadaga gapjagi useumeul teotteuryeoseo modureul nollage haesseoyo.
examples.en: He was talking and then suddenly burst out laughing, surprising everyone.

examples.kr: 난 집에 가다가 친구와 우연히 만나서 함께 저녁을 먹었어요.
examples.romaji: Nan jibe gadaga chinguwa uyeonhi mannaseo hamkke jeonyeogeul meogeosseoyo.
examples.en: I was on my way home, then ran into a friend by chance and had dinner together.

title: ~(으)던 [(eu)deon] (Who used to)
short_explanation: This is used to describe an action or state that used to exist in the past but does not exist now.
long_explanation: '~(으)던' is used when referring back to a past action or state that has since ended or changed. It corresponds to 'who used to' or 'that used to' in English. It often implies something was habitual or continuous, or it was once true but is no longer so.

examples.kr: 나는 어릴 때 많이 울던 아이였어요. 그런데 지금은 거의 울지 않아요.
examples.romaji: Naneun eoril ttae mani uldeon aiyeosseoyo. Geureonde jigeumeun geoui ulji anhayo.
examples.en: I used to be a child who cried a lot when I was young, but now I rarely cry.

examples.kr: 그는 어렸을 때 언제나 사과를 좋아하던 사람이었어요. 하지만 지금은 사과를 싫어해요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun eoryeosseul ttae eonjena sagwareul joahadeon saramieosseoyo. Hajiman jigeumeun sagwareul silheohaeyo.
examples.en: He always used to like apples when he was young, but now he dislikes them.

examples.kr: 우리 학교에는 많은 학생들이 수학을 싫어하던 선생님이 있었어요.
examples.romaji: Uri hakgyoeneun maneun haksengdeuri suhageul silheohadeon seonsaengnim-i isseosseoyo.
examples.en: There was a teacher in our school whom many students used to dislike for math.

examples.kr: 그녀는 앞산에 살던 친절한 아주머니였습니다. 하지만 이젠 그녀를 볼 수 없어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun apsane saldeon chinjeolhan ajumeoniyeosseumnida. Hajiman ijen geunyeoreul bol su eopseoyo.
examples.en: She was a kind lady who used to live on the mountainside, but now we can't see her anymore.

title: ~(으)려면 [(eu)ryeomyeon] (In order to)
short_explanation: Used to express the condition or criteria needed to realize a certain goal or result; 'in order to', 'if one wants to'.
long_explanation: '~(으)려면' is used in Korean to present the conditions required to achieve a particular outcome or goal. It can be translated as 'in order to' or 'if you want to'. It emphasizes that certain conditions must be met for the intended result to happen.
formation: Verb stem + 으려면 (if ending in a consonant) / Verb stem + 려면 (if ending in a vowel)

examples.kr: 한국어 TOPIK 시험에 합격하려면 많이 연습해야 합니다. 그렇지 않으면 성공하기 어려워요.
examples.romaji: Hangugeo TOPIK siheome hapgyeokharyeomyeon mani yeonseubhaeya hamnida. Geureochi aneumyeon seonggonghagi eoryeowoyo.
examples.en: In order to pass the Korean TOPIK exam, you have to practice a lot. Otherwise, it will be difficult to succeed.

examples.kr: 헬스 클럽에서 몸매를 유지하려면 꾸준히 운동하고 건강한 식단을 유지해야 해요.
examples.romaji: Heulseu keulleobeseo mommaereul yujiharyeomyeon kkujunhi undonghago geonganghan sikdaneul yujihaeya haeyo.
examples.en: In order to maintain a good figure at the gym, you must exercise regularly and keep a healthy diet.

examples.kr: 이 직업을 얻으려면 관련 분야에서의 경험이 필요해요. 없으면 경쟁력이 부족할 거예요.
examples.romaji: I jigeobeul eoduryeomyeon gwallyeon bunyaeseoui gyeongheomi pilyohaeyo. Eopseumyeon gyeongjaengryeogi bujokhal geoyeyo.
examples.en: To get this job, you need experience in this field. Without it, you'll lack competitiveness.

examples.kr: 이런 문제를 방지하려면 좀 더 세심한 계획이 필요해요. 그렇지 않으면 같은 문제를 또 겪을 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Ireon munjereul bangjiharyeomyeon jom deo sesimhan gyehoegi pilyohaeyo. Geureochi aneumyeon gateun munjereul tto gyeokeul su isseoyo.
examples.en: In order to prevent this type of issue, a more meticulous plan is needed. Otherwise, we might face the same problems again.

title: ~(으)ㄹ 수록 [(eu)l surok] (The more)
short_explanation: Used to express an increase in degree, intensity, or extent; 'the more... the more...'.
long_explanation: '~(으)ㄹ수록' is a pattern used to show that one action or state increasingly affects another, similar to 'the more... the more...' in English. It indicates that as one element increases (or decreases), another is affected proportionally.

examples.kr: 운동을 할수록 건강해지니까 매일 아침에 조깅하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Undongeul halsurok geonganghaejinikka maeil achime joginghago isseoyo.
examples.en: The more I exercise, the healthier I get, so I jog every morning.

examples.kr: 공부를 많이 할수록 시험에서 더 좋은 점수를 받을 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Gongbureul mani halsurok siheomeseo deo joheun jeomsureul badeul su isseoyo.
examples.en: The more you study, the higher score you can get on the exam.

examples.kr: 음식을 빨리 먹을수록 소화가 잘 안 될 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Eumsigeul ppalli meogeulsurok sohwaga jal an doel su isseoyo.
examples.en: The faster you eat, the more likely you are to have indigestion.

examples.kr: 시간이 지날수록 그리움이 더 깊어져요.
examples.romaji: Sigani jinalsurok geuriumi deo gipeojyeoyo.
examples.en: The more time passes, the deeper my longing becomes.

title: ~(으)ㄴ/는 중 [(eu)n/neun jung] (In the middle of)
short_explanation: Used to indicate 'in the process' or 'in the middle of' certain actions or states.
long_explanation: '~(으)ㄴ/는 중' is used in Korean to express ongoing actions or states, similar to continuous/progressive forms in English. It suggests that the speaker (or subject) is 'in the middle of' doing something right now, or is currently in some state. The form depends on whether the verb ends in a vowel or consonant.
formation: Verb stem + ~(으)ㄴ 중 or 는 중

examples.kr: 저는 지금 숙제를 하는 중이라서 나중에 연락 드릴게요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun jigeum sukjereul haneun jungiraseo najunge yeollak deurilgeyo.
examples.en: I'm in the middle of doing my homework right now, so I'll contact you later.

examples.kr: 오빠는 여자친구와 통화하는 중이라서 바쁜 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Oppaneun yeojachinguwa tonghwahaneun jungiraseo bappeun geot gatayo.
examples.en: My older brother seems busy because he's in the middle of talking to his girlfriend.

examples.kr: 우리 엄마는 계속 질문하는 중이라서 집중이 잘 안 돼요.
examples.romaji: Uri eommaneun gyesok jilmunhaneun jungiraseo jipjungi jal andwaeyo.
examples.en: My mom keeps asking questions, so I'm not able to concentrate well.

examples.kr: 그녀는 재미있는 영화를 보는 중이에요, 그래서 웃고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun jaemiinneun yeonghwareul boneun jungieyo, geuraeseo utgo isseoyo.
examples.en: She is in the middle of watching an interesting movie, so she's laughing.

title: ~(으)ㄴ/는 탓에 [(eu)n/neun tase] (Because of)
short_explanation: Used to express the cause of a negative result or situation; 'because of'.
long_explanation: '~(으)ㄴ/는 탓에' is a grammar point in Korean used to express that a particular cause led to a negative or undesirable outcome. It is akin to 'because of' in English when something unfortunate happens due to a specified reason.

examples.kr: 나무를 너무 많이 베어서 우리 동네의 환경이 나쁜 탓에 사람들이 많이 아파요.
examples.romaji: Namureul neomu mani be-eoseo uri dongnaeui hwangyeongi nappeun tase saramdeuri mani apayo.
examples.en: Because we cut down too many trees, the poor environment in our neighborhood is making many people sick.

examples.kr: 지난주에 너무 많이 먹은 탓에 이번 주에 체중이 늘었어요.
examples.romaji: Jinanju-e neomu mani meogeun tase ibeon jue chejungi neuleosseoyo.
examples.en: Because I ate too much last week, I gained weight this week.

examples.kr: 연습을 충분히 하지 않은 탓에 시험에서 좋은 점수를 받지 못했어요.
examples.romaji: Yeonseubeul chungbunhi haji anheun tase siheomeseo joheun jeomsureul batji mothaesseoyo.
examples.en: Because I didn't practice enough, I didn't receive a good score on the test.

examples.kr: 엄마가 재료를 사러 가야 했는데 막차를 놓친 탓에 오늘은 요리를 못 해요.
examples.romaji: Eommaga jaeryoreul sareo gaya haetneunde magchareul nochin tase oneureun yorireul mot haeyo.
examples.en: Mom had to go buy ingredients, but she missed the last bus, so we can't cook today.

title: ~(으)ㄴ/는데다가 [(eu)n/neundedaga] (Moreover, additionally)
short_explanation: Used to add more information, similar to 'moreover' or 'additionally' in English.
long_explanation: '~(으)ㄴ/는데다가' is a compound grammar form in Korean used to add an extra piece of information on top of what was already mentioned, similar to 'moreover', 'besides', or 'furthermore' in English. It can attach to verbs, adjectives, or nouns (with the right connectors), providing an additional detail or characteristic that reinforces what came before.

examples.kr: 이 카페는 분위기도 좋은 데다가 커피 맛도 훌륭해요.
examples.romaji: I kape-neun bunwigido joheun dedaga keopi matdo hullyunghaeyo.
examples.en: This cafe not only has a good atmosphere, but moreover, the coffee tastes great.

examples.kr: 그 책은 재미있는 데다가 유익하기까지 해요.
examples.romaji: Geu chaeg-eun jaemiinneun dedaga yuikhagikkaji haeyo.
examples.en: That book is interesting, and additionally, it's informative.

examples.kr: 이 핸드폰은 가격이 저렴한 데다가 기능도 다양해요.
examples.romaji: I haendeupon-eun gagyeogi jeoryeomhan dedaga gineungdo dayanghaeyo.
examples.en: This phone is inexpensive and, moreover, it has a wide range of features.

examples.kr: 그는 착한 데다가 똑똑하기까지 해서 모두가 그를 좋아해요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun chakan dedaga ttokttokhagikkaji haeseo moduga geureul joahaeyo.
examples.en: He’s kind, and on top of that, he’s smart, so everyone likes him.

title: ~(으)ㄴ/는데도 불구하고 [(eu)n/neundedo bulguhago] (Despite, in spite of)
short_explanation: Used to express 'despite' or 'in spite of'.
long_explanation: '~(으)ㄴ/는데도 불구하고' is a longer conjunction in Korean that indicates a counter-expected result. It means 'despite' or 'in spite of' the first clause, the second (often unexpected) result still happened. It emphasizes that the outcome defies the expectation one might have based on the first clause.
formation: Adjective/Verb in past or present tense + ~(으)ㄴ/는데도 불구하고

examples.kr: 비가 오는데도 불구하고 그녀는 나가서 신나게 놀았어요.
examples.romaji: Biga oneundedo bulguhago geunyeoneun nagaseo sinnage norasseoyo.
examples.en: Despite the rain, she went out and had a blast.

examples.kr: 그는 아픈데도 불구하고 학교에 갔어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun apeundedo bulguhago hakgyoe gasseoyo.
examples.en: Despite being sick, he went to school.

examples.kr: 원하는 결과를 얻지 못했는데도 불구하고 우리는 계속 노력했어요.
examples.romaji: Wonhaneun gyeolgwareul eodji mothaesseunde-do bulguhago urineun gyesok noryeokhaesseoyo.
examples.en: Even though we couldn’t get the results we wanted, we kept trying.

examples.kr: 시험이 어려운데도 불구하고 그는 잘 봤어요.
examples.romaji: Siheomi eoryeoundedo bulguhago geuneun jal bwasseoyo.
examples.en: Despite the exam being difficult, he did well on it.

title: ~(으)ㄴ/는지 모르겠다 [(eu)n/neunji moreugessda] (I'm not sure if)
short_explanation: Used to express uncertainty or lack of confidence about something; 'I'm not sure if'.
long_explanation: '~(으)ㄴ/는지 모르겠다' is used in Korean when the speaker is not certain about some fact or situation. It often corresponds to 'I don't know if...' or 'I'm not sure whether...' in English. You attach ~(으)ㄴ/는지 to the verb or adjective stem, then add 모르겠다 (or 모른다, 모르겠어요, etc.) to indicate uncertainty.

examples.kr: 저는 장소를 정확하게 기억하고 나왔는지 모르겠어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun jangsoreul jeonghwakage gieokhago nawassneunji moreugesseoyo.
examples.en: I'm not sure if I remembered the location correctly when I left.

examples.kr: 그가 아직도 나를 사랑하는지 모르겠어요.
examples.romaji: Geuga ajikdo nareul saranghaneunji moreugesseoyo.
examples.en: I'm not sure if he still loves me.

examples.kr: 비가 왔었는지 모르겠는데, 바닥이 젖어 있네요.
examples.romaji: Biga wasseonneunji moreugenneunde, badagi jeojeo inneyo.
examples.en: I'm not sure if it rained, but the ground is wet.

examples.kr: 내일 학교에 갈 수 있는지 모르겠어요. 몸이 좀 안 좋아요.
examples.romaji: Naeil hakgyoe gal su inneunji moreugesseoyo. Momi jom an joayo.
examples.en: I'm not sure if I can go to school tomorrow. I’m feeling a bit unwell.

title: ~(으)려는 참이다 [(eu)ryeoneun chamida] (I really want to)
short_explanation: Used to express a strong desire or intention to do something, often implying frustration at not being able to do it.
long_explanation: '~(으)려는 참이다' emphasizes a strong intent or desire toward an action, sometimes accompanied by a sense of frustration or impatience. It can be translated as 'I was just about to...' or 'I really want to...' in English. It's commonly used when you feel you have been holding yourself back but are on the verge of acting.

examples.kr: 이 사람에게 뭐라고 하려는 참이었지만, 말을 꺼낼 수가 없었어요.
examples.romaji: I saramege mworago haryeoneun chamieotjiman, mareul kkeonael suga eopseosseoyo.
examples.en: I really wanted to say something to this person, but I couldn’t bring myself to speak.

examples.kr: 반말하려는 참이었지만 그를 존중해서 참았어요.
examples.romaji: Banmal haryeoneun chamieotjiman geureul jonjunghaeseo chamasseoyo.
examples.en: I really wanted to speak informally, but I held back out of respect for him.

examples.kr: 야외에서 놀려는 참이었지만 날씨가 너무 안 좋아서 못 했어요.
examples.romaji: Yawoeseo nolryeoneun chamieotjiman nalssiga neomu an joaseo mot haesseoyo.
examples.en: I really wanted to play outside, but I couldn’t because the weather was too bad.

examples.kr: 그 영화를 보려는 참이었는데 표가 매진이라서 못 봤어요.
examples.romaji: Geu yeonghwareul boryeoneun chamieotneunde pyoga maejiniraseo mot bwasseoyo.
examples.en: I really wanted to watch that movie, but I couldn’t because it was sold out.

title: ~(으)ㄹ 것 같다 [(eu)l geot gatda] (It seems like)
short_explanation: Used to express a guess, assumption, or prediction.
long_explanation: '~(으)ㄹ 것 같다' is used to say that something seems like it will happen, or that you assume/predict something based on what you know. Whether you use '으' depends on whether the verb/adjective stem ends in a consonant or vowel. In casual speech, you’ll often hear it as '것 같아(요).'

examples.kr: 내일은 비가 올 것 같아요. 우산을 챙기는 게 좋겠어요.
examples.romaji: Naeireun biga ol geot gatayo. Usaneul chaengingeun ge jokesseoyo.
examples.en: It seems like it will rain tomorrow. You’d better bring an umbrella.

examples.kr: 그녀는 매우 행복할 것 같아요. 드디어 드림팀에 합류했으니까요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun maeu haengbokhal geot gatayo. Deudieo deurimtime habryuhaesseunikka-yo.
examples.en: She seems like she'll be really happy, because she finally joined her dream team.

examples.kr: 이 지도를 보니까 우리가 길을 잃을 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: I jidoreul bonikka uriga gireul ilheul geot gatayo.
examples.en: Looking at this map, it seems like we might lose our way.

examples.kr: 이 제품은 인기가 높을 것 같아요. 기능이 매우 뛰어나거든요.
examples.romaji: I jepumeun ingiga nopeul geot gatayo. Gineungi maeu ttwieonagodeunyo.
examples.en: It seems like this product will be popular because its features are excellent.

title: ~(으)ㄹ 것이다 [(eu)l geosida] (Will likely)
short_explanation: Used to express probability, anticipation, or plan for the future; 'will likely', 'will', 'is going to'.
long_explanation: '~(으)ㄹ 것이다' is used in Korean to indicate a prediction, expectation, or plan regarding the future, akin to 'will' in English. It implies the speaker’s belief or intention about what will happen or what they (or someone else) will do.
formation: Verb stem + ㄹ 것이다 (if ending in a vowel) / 을 것이다 (if ending in a consonant)

examples.kr: 내일은 날씨가 좋을 것이다. 그래서 다들 야외에서 시간을 보내려고 할 것이다.
examples.romaji: Naeireun nalssiga joheul geosida. Geuraeseo dadeul yaoeseo siganeul bonaeryeogo hal geosida.
examples.en: The weather will likely be good tomorrow, so everyone will probably plan to spend time outdoors.

examples.kr: 저는 내년에 대학교를 졸업할 것이다. 그리고 취업을 준비할 것이다.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun naenyeone daehakgyoreul joleophal geosida. Geurigo chwieobeul junbihal geosida.
examples.en: I will likely graduate from university next year, and I will prepare to get a job.

examples.kr: 우리는 이번 주말에 캠핑을 갈 것이다. 그래서 캠핑용품을 살 것이다.
examples.romaji: Urineun ibeon jumale kaempingeul gal geosida. Geuraeseo kaempingyongpumeul sal geosida.
examples.en: We will likely go camping this weekend, so we plan to buy camping gear.

examples.kr: 그녀는 피아노 연습을 많이 하고 있으니까 곧 잘 칠 것이다.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun piano yeonseubeul manhi hago isseunikka got jal chil geosida.
examples.en: Since she has been practicing the piano a lot, she will likely play well soon.

title: ~(으)ㄹ 뿐만 아니라 [(eu)l ppunman anira] (Not only... but also...)
short_explanation: Used to express 'not only..., but also...'.
long_explanation: '~(으)ㄹ 뿐만 아니라' is used in Korean to emphasize two or more statements are true. The second part adds new information that supports or expands upon the first part, akin to 'not only…but also…' in English.

examples.kr: 그는 일을 잘할 뿐만 아니라 창조성도 뛰어나서 모두에게 인정을 받았어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun ireul jalhal ppunman anira changjoseongdo ttwieonaseo moduege injungeul badasseoyo.
examples.en: Not only does he do his job well, but he’s also very creative, so everyone recognizes him.

examples.kr: 이 레스토랑은 맛있는 음식을 제공할 뿐만 아니라 훌륭한 서비스도 제공해요.
examples.romaji: I reseutorang-eun masinneun eumsigeul jegonghal ppunman anira hullyunghan seobiseudo jegonghaeyo.
examples.en: This restaurant not only provides delicious food but also excellent service.

examples.kr: 그녀는 영어를 잘할 뿐만 아니라 중국어와 일본어도 유창해요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun yeongeoreul jalhal ppunman anira junggueowa ilboneodo yuchanghaeyo.
examples.en: She is not only good at English, but she’s also fluent in Chinese and Japanese.

examples.kr: 지민 씨는 요리를 잘할 뿐만 아니라 정말 멋진 사진도 찍을 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Jimin ssi-neun yorireul jalhal ppunman anira jeongmal meotjin sajindo jjigeul su isseoyo.
examples.en: Not only can Jimin cook well, but he can also take really amazing photos.

title: ~(으)ㄹ 뿐이다 [(eu)l ppunida] (Only, just)
short_explanation: Used to express 'only' or 'just', emphasizing a sole action or state.
long_explanation: '~(으)ㄹ 뿐이다' emphasizes that there is nothing more or different beyond what’s stated. It’s similar to saying 'I only do X' or 'It’s just that…' in English. The form depends on whether the verb stem ends in a vowel (ㄹ 뿐이다) or consonant (을 뿐이다).

examples.kr: 그녀는 말할 뿐이지, 실제로 행동하지 않아요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun malhal ppuniji, siljero haengdonghaji anhayo.
examples.en: She only talks; she doesn't actually take any action.

examples.kr: 나는 그녀에게 웃을 뿐이다. 실제로 대화는 하지 않았어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun geunyeoege useul ppunida. Siljero daehwaneun haji anhasseoyo.
examples.en: I just smiled at her; I didn’t actually have any conversation.

examples.kr: 아버지는 손님들과 대화할 뿐이지 집안일을 돕지 않아요.
examples.romaji: Abeojineun sonnimdeulgwa daehwahal ppuniji jibanireul dopji anhayo.
examples.en: Father only talks with the guests; he doesn't help with the housework.

examples.kr: 그들은 영화만 보러 갈 뿐이다. 영화에 대해 이야기하진 않아요.
examples.romaji: Geudeureun yeonghwaman boreo gal ppunida. Yeonghwa-e daehae iyagihajin anhayo.
examples.en: They’re just going to watch a movie. They don’t actually discuss it.

title: ~(으)ㄹ게요 [(eu)lgeyo] (I will, in the future)
short_explanation: Used to express an intention or promise about the future, often showing the speaker’s determination.
long_explanation: '~(으)ㄹ게요' is a polite way in Korean to show the speaker’s intention or promise to do something soon. It also conveys the speaker’s will to carry out the action. Which form (을게요 or ㄹ게요) you use depends on the final sound of the verb stem.

examples.kr: 제가 직접 전화해서 진행 상황을 알려 드릴게요.
examples.romaji: Jega jigjeop jeonhwahaeseo jinhaeng sanghwang-eul allyeo deurilgeyo.
examples.en: I will call personally to let you know the progress.

examples.kr: 이 짐은 제가 갖고 갈게요. 너무 무거우니까 걱정하지 마세요.
examples.romaji: I jim-eun jega gajgo galgeyo. Neomu mugeounikka geokjeonghaji maseyo.
examples.en: I will carry this luggage. Don’t worry because it’s quite heavy.

examples.kr: 과제를 내일까지 끝내고 보고서도 쓸게요.
examples.romaji: Gwajereul naeilkkaji kkeutnaego bogoseodo seulgeyo.
examples.en: I will finish the assignment by tomorrow and also write the report.

examples.kr: 오늘 저녁에 모두 모이면 제가 음식을 만들어서 가져올게요.
examples.romaji: Oneul jeonyeoge modu moimyeon jega eumsigeul mandeureoseo gajyeo-olgeyo.
examples.en: When everyone gathers this evening, I will cook and bring the food.

title: ~(으)ㄹ게 [(eu)lge] (I will, in the future)
short_explanation: A casual way to indicate the speaker will do something in the future, often reflecting one’s decision or promise.
long_explanation: '~(으)ㄹ게' is the casual version of '~(으)ㄹ게요', used among friends or people of the same age. It expresses the speaker’s intention or promise to do something soon. As with '~(으)ㄹ게요', the form depends on the final sound of the verb stem.

examples.kr: 나는 내일부터 다이어트할게. 오늘까지만 맛있는 음식 먹을 거야.
examples.romaji: Naneun naeilbuteo daieoteu halge. Oneulkkajiman masinneun eumsik meogeul geoya.
examples.en: I’ll start dieting from tomorrow. I’ll only eat delicious food until today.

examples.kr: 너무 걱정하지 마. 한국어 공부 열심히 할게.
examples.romaji: Neomu geokjeonghaji ma. Hangugeo gongbu yeolsimhi halge.
examples.en: Don't worry too much. I’ll study Korean diligently.

examples.kr: 미안해. 지금부터는 절대 늦지 않을게.
examples.romaji: Mianhae. Jigeumbuteoneun jeoldae neutji anheulge.
examples.en: I’m sorry. From now on, I’ll never be late.

examples.kr: 방 청소를 안 했어? 괜찮아, 나중에 내가 할게.
examples.romaji: Bang cheongso-reul an haesseo? Gwaenchanha, najunge naega halge.
examples.en: You didn’t clean the room? It’s okay, I’ll do it later.

title: ~(으)ㄹ래 [(eu)llae] (I want to)
short_explanation: Used to express that the speaker wants or intends to do something, usually in casual speech.
long_explanation: '~(으)ㄹ래' is used in casual Korean to indicate the speaker’s desire or plan to do something. It can translate to 'I want to…' or 'Shall we…?' depending on context. It is more informal than '~(으)ㄹ게요.'

examples.kr: 오늘 저녁에 바베큐를 먹을래. 스테이크 하우스에 가고 싶어서.
examples.romaji: Oneul jeonyeoge babekyureul meogeullae. Seuteikeu hause-e gago sipaseo.
examples.en: I want to have BBQ tonight. I feel like going to a steakhouse.

examples.kr: 내일 친구들이랑 영화를 볼래. 요즘 재미있는 영화가 많잖아.
examples.romaji: Naeil chingudeurirang yeonghwareul bollae. Yojeum jaemiinneun yeonghwaga manjana.
examples.en: I want to watch a movie with my friends tomorrow. There are lots of fun movies lately.

examples.kr: 주말에 소풍 갈래? 날씨가 좋을 것 같아.
examples.romaji: Jumare sopung gallae? Nalssiga joeul geot gata.
examples.en: Shall we go on a picnic this weekend? The weather seems like it’ll be nice.

examples.kr: 새로운 취미를 찾을래. 지금까지 하던 게 좀 지루해졌어.
examples.romaji: Saeroun chwimireul chajeullae. Jigeumkkaji hadeon ge jom jiruhaejyeosseo.
examples.en: I want to find a new hobby. The one I've had so far has gotten a bit boring.

title: ~(으)ㄹ라고 [(eu)llago] (Intend to)
short_explanation: Used to express someone's intention or plan to do something (colloquial).
long_explanation: '~(으)ㄹ라고' is a somewhat colloquial form in Korean for expressing plans or intentions. It can be attached to a verb stem to indicate what someone is determined or plans to do. If the verb stem ends in a vowel or 'ㄹ', use 'ㄹ라고'; otherwise use '을라고'.

examples.kr: 그는 내일 아침에 일찍 일어날라고 알람을 맞춰 놨어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun naeil achime iljjik ireonallago allameul matchwo nwasseoyo.
examples.en: He set an alarm because he intends to wake up early tomorrow morning.

examples.kr: 지민이는 축구 대회에서 우승할라고 매일 연습하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Jiminineun chukgu daehoeeseo useunghallago maeil yeonseuphago isseoyo.
examples.en: Jimin practices every day because he intends to win the soccer tournament.

examples.kr: 서연이는 결혼할라고 집을 구입할 계획을 세우고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Seoyeonineun gyeolhonhallago jibeul guiphal gyehoeg-eul seugo isseoyo.
examples.en: Seoyeon is planning to buy a house because she intends to get married.

examples.kr: 나는 이번 달에 새 차를 살라고 돈을 모으고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun ibeon dare sae chareul sallago doneul mo-eugo isseoyo.
examples.en: I’m saving money this month because I intend to buy a new car.

title: ~(으)ㄹ 테니까 [(eu)l tenikka] (Since I assume)
short_explanation: Used when the speaker makes a guess or assumption, then provides advice or a suggestion based on that assumption.
long_explanation: '~(으)ㄹ 테니까' indicates a future assumption or strong belief about a situation, followed by advice or a suggestion. It shows that the speaker is giving guidance or instructions that hinge on this assumption.

examples.kr: 너무 늦어질 테니까 이제 집에 가는 게 좋겠어요.
examples.romaji: Neomu neujeojil tenikka ije jibe ganeun ge jokgesseoyo.
examples.en: It’s going to get too late, so you should probably head home now.

examples.kr: 비가 올 테니까 우산을 가져가세요.
examples.romaji: Biga ol tenikka usaneul gajyeogaseyo.
examples.en: It’s likely to rain, so take an umbrella.

examples.kr: 내일 시험이 있을 테니까 오늘 밤에는 공부하는 게 좋겠어요.
examples.romaji: Naeil siheomi isseul tenikka oneul bamenen gongbuhaneun ge jokgesseoyo.
examples.en: Since there’s probably a test tomorrow, you should study tonight.

examples.kr: 그는 이미 알고 있을 테니까 너무 걱정하지 마세요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun imi algo isseul tenikka neomu geokjeonghaji maseyo.
examples.en: He probably already knows, so don’t worry too much.

title: ~(으)ㄹ지라도 [(eu)ljirado] (Even if)
short_explanation: Used to express 'even if', emphasizing that a certain action or decision remains unchanged regardless of the situation.
long_explanation: '~(으)ㄹ지라도' is a complex suffix used in Korean to signify 'even if' or 'although'. It is commonly used for mentioning a hypothetical or difficult scenario, yet affirming that one’s stance or decision does not change. It emphasizes the speaker’s firm determination or resolution in spite of possible negative outcomes.

examples.kr: 이 일이 얼마나 어려울지라도, 저는 반드시 해내겠어요.
examples.romaji: I iri eolmana eoryeouljirado, jeoneun bandeusi haenaegesseoyo.
examples.en: No matter how difficult this task may be, I will definitely finish it.

examples.kr: 자고 싶을지라도, 다가오는 시험 때문에 밤새 공부해야 해요.
examples.romaji: Jago sipeuljirado, dagaoneun siheom ttaemune bamsae gongbuhaya haeyo.
examples.en: Even though I want to sleep, I have to study all night because of the upcoming exam.

examples.kr: 비가 오지 않을지라도, 우산을 항상 가지고 다녀야 해요.
examples.romaji: Biga oji anheuljirado, usaneul hangsang gajigo danyeoya haeyo.
examples.en: Even if it doesn't rain, you should always carry an umbrella.

examples.kr: 날씨가 추울지라도, 저는 언제나 아이스크림을 먹고 싶어요.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga chuuljirado, jeoneun eonjena aiseukeurimeul meokgo sipeoyo.
examples.en: Even if it's cold, I always want to eat ice cream.

title: ~(으)면서도 [(eu)myeonseodo] (While, although)
short_explanation: Used to express contrast or contradiction; 'while', 'although'.
long_explanation: '~(으)면서도' is used in Korean to show that two actions or states occur simultaneously, yet they are somewhat contradictory or unexpected when considered together. It is akin to saying 'while' or 'even though' in English.

examples.kr: 그녀는 아프면서도 일을 계속했습니다. 아픔을 이겨내고 일을 마무리했어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun apeumyeonseodo ireul gyesokhaetsseumnida. Apeumeul igyeonaego ireul mamurihaesseoyo.
examples.en: Although she was sick, she kept working. She overcame the pain and finished her work.

examples.kr: 비가 오면서도 축제는 계속됐어요. 모두들 즐거움에 흠뻑 빠져들었죠.
examples.romaji: Biga omyeonseodo chukjeneun gyesok dwaesseoyo. Modudeul jeulgeoume heumppok ppajyeodeureotjyo.
examples.en: Even though it was raining, the festival continued. Everyone was fully immersed in the fun.

examples.kr: 그는 실수를 하면서도 끝까지 포기하지 않았습니다. 그의 집중력과 끈기는 대단했어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun silsureul hamyeonseodo ggeutkkaji pogihaji anatsseumnida. Geuui jipjungnyeokgwa kkeungineun daedanhaesseoyo.
examples.en: Even though he made mistakes, he never gave up until the end. His focus and perseverance were amazing.

examples.kr: 식사를 다 하면서도 배가 고픈 것 같았어요. 너무 많이 달려서 그런 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Siksareul da hamyeonseodo baega gopeun geot gatasseoyo. Neomu mani dallyeoseo geureon geot gatayo.
examples.en: Although I had finished eating, I still felt hungry. I think it’s because I ran so much.

title: ~(으)시면 [(eu)simyeon] (If you)
short_explanation: Used to express a polite conditional, translating to 'if you' or 'when you' in English.
long_explanation: '~(으)시면' is a polite conditional form used to say 'if you...' or 'when you...' in a respectful way. It is often directed at someone of equal or higher status, indicating a formal or polite tone.

examples.kr: 편하시면 오늘 저녁에 저에게 전화해 주시겠어요?
examples.romaji: Pyeonhasimyeon oneul jeonyeoge jeoege jeonhwahae jusigesseoyo?
examples.en: If it's convenient for you, could you call me tonight?

examples.kr: 수업이 끝나시면 자기소개를 시작해 주시면 감사하겠습니다.
examples.romaji: Sueobi kkeutnasimyeon jagi sogaereul sijakhae jusimyeon gamsahabnida.
examples.en: I would appreciate it if you could start your self-introduction when the class ends.

examples.kr: 가능하시면 내일 회의에 참석해 주실 수 있을까요?
examples.romaji: Ganeunghasimyeon naeil hoeuie chamseokhae jusil su isseulkkayo?
examples.en: If it's possible, could you attend the meeting tomorrow?

examples.kr: 시간 나시면 사진 몇 장 보여주시면 감사하겠습니다.
examples.romaji: Sigan nasimyeon sajin myeot jang boyeojusimyeon gamsahabnida.
examples.en: If you have time, I'd appreciate it if you showed me a few photos.

title: ~(으)시겠어요 [(eu)sigesseoyo] (You will probably)
short_explanation: Used to express probability or an assumption about the listener’s action or state, in a polite way.
long_explanation: '~(으)시겠어요' is a polite form in Korean used to express the speaker’s assumption or expectation about the listener’s future condition or action. It conveys respect and is often used in formal or semi-formal conversation.

examples.kr: 날씨가 꽤 춥네요. 당신은 목도리를 하시겠어요.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga kkwae chumneyo. Dangsineun mokdorireul hasigesseoyo.
examples.en: The weather is quite cold, so you'll probably wear a scarf.

examples.kr: 정말 바쁜 하루셨죠? 많이 피곤하시겠어요.
examples.romaji: Jeongmal bappeun harusyeotjyo? Mani pigonhasigesseoyo.
examples.en: You had a really busy day, right? You must be very tired.

examples.kr: 이렇게 일이 많으니 주말에도 일하시겠어요.
examples.romaji: Ireoke iri manheuni jumaredo ilhasigesseoyo.
examples.en: Since there's so much work, you'll probably have to work over the weekend.

examples.kr: 날씨가 이렇게 더우니 시원한 음료수를 좋아하시겠어요.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga ireohge deouni siwonhan eumryosureul joahasigesseoyo.
examples.en: Because the weather is so hot, you'd probably like a cool drink.

title: ~(으)ㅂ시다 [(eu)bshida] (Let's)
short_explanation: Used to propose or suggest an activity together; 'Let's'.
long_explanation: '~(으)ㅂ시다' is the standard form in Korean used to suggest doing something together, equivalent to 'Let's' in English. The form depends on whether the verb stem ends in a vowel (ㅂ시다) or consonant (읍시다).

examples.kr: 오늘 저녁 식당에서 저녁을 먹읍시다. 다른 모든 일들은 잊어버려요.
examples.romaji: Oneul jeonyeok sikdang-eseo jeonyeogeul meogeupsida. Dareun modeun ildeureun ijeobeoryeoyo.
examples.en: Let's eat dinner at a restaurant tonight and forget everything else.

examples.kr: 우리 함께 산책합시다. 다들 기분 전환이 될 거예요.
examples.romaji: Uri hamkke sanchaeghapsida. Dadeul gibun jeonhwani doel geoyeyo.
examples.en: Let's take a walk together. It’ll help everyone refresh.

examples.kr: 이 문제를 같이 해결합시다. 함께하면 더 쉬울 거예요.
examples.romaji: I munjereul gachi haegyeolhapsida. Hamkkehamyeon deo swiwul geoyeyo.
examples.en: Let's solve this problem together. It will be easier if we do it together.

examples.kr: 모두 같이 여행 갑시다. 같이 가면 훨씬 즐거울 거예요.
examples.romaji: Modu gachi yeohaeng gapsida. Gachi gamyeon hwolssin jeulgeoul geoyeyo.
examples.en: Let's all go on a trip together. It will be much more fun if we go together.

title: ~(으)십시오 [(eu)sipsio] (Please)
short_explanation: Used to express polite requests or commands; roughly 'please do ~'.
long_explanation: '~(으)십시오' is one of the most formal imperative endings in Korean, used to give commands or requests politely. It corresponds to 'please do ~' in English. Whether you use '십시오' or '으십시오' depends on whether the verb stem ends in a vowel or a consonant.

examples.kr: 한 번 더 생각해보십시오. 아마 그것이 올바른 선택일 것입니다.
examples.romaji: Han beon deo saenggakhaebosipsio. Ama geugeosi olbareun seontaegil geosimnida.
examples.en: Please think it over once more. It might be the right choice.

examples.kr: 여기 앉으십시오. 드릴 말씀이 있습니다.
examples.romaji: Yeogi anjeusipsio. Deuril malsseumi itsseumnida.
examples.en: Please sit here. I have something to tell you.

examples.kr: 집에 오셨다면, 먼저 손을 씻으십시오.
examples.romaji: Jibe osyeotdamyeon, meonjeo soneul sseuseupsio.
examples.en: If you have come home, please wash your hands first.

examples.kr: 궁금증이 있다면 그 질문을 지금 물어보십시오.
examples.romaji: Gunggeumjeungi itdamyeon geu jilmuneul jigeum mureobosipsio.
examples.en: If you have any questions, please ask them now.
